PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War list of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.

Your humble petitioners pray that the Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.

And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petitioning letter bearing 53 signatures and requesting that legislation to implement the proposed charter of residents' rights, as recommended in the report of residents' rights in nursing homes and hostels, be rejected:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr McLean

The viability of the nursing home industry's very existence is totally threatened under current Federal Government policy. The great care and compassion that we continue to give to the sick and elderly in our nursing homes is being undermined by the Hawke Government in Canberra.

Under the guise of ``reforms'' we are suffering financial and staffing cuts to our nursing homes. The Federal Government is making it medically harder and harder for the sick elderly to pass medical assessments to obtain admission to nursing homes.
We can only presume they are supporting their clearly stated goal to see the sick aged back in the family home and the responsibility of relatives at no cost to the government.

We are particularly concerned to stop legislation of the proposed Patients Bill of Rights which comes out of the Government report ``Residents Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels''. If legislated all residents would be forced to sign a contract as part of pre-admission procedure. In this contract there are innumerable issues which could create horrendous legal problems for directors of nursing, staff and proprietors. For example, no resident (even if highly dangerous) will be able to be evicted from the home for a minimum of 42 days. Likewise, if all residents have total freedom in social and personal relationships it will be extremely difficult for staff to censure the undesirable behaviour that does occur with some residents.

Some of the sick elderly in our care are not emotionally well. Yet they will have a contract of rights and external avenues to complain and appeal as they wish against any staff decisions made in the interests of the home.

The administration and documentation which will be required by the contract will take up valuable time for staff who have already lost many of the hours they need for nursing care. If the contract is legislated there will be implications which are dangerous to staff and residents. For example, dementia patients will have the right to wander and do great harm to themselves and others. Smoking in bed could burn the home down.
There will be feelings of mistrust and uncertainty created between staff and residents. Who will look after staff rights or pay for the legal representation they will certainly require?

Many of the recommendations in the report cost money, particularly extra material luxuries such as more variety in menus, telephones, furniture etc. If they are legislated, who will pay for their implementation? Many nursing homes, particularly smaller ones, are already closing through the government's monetary cuts. Yet, it is surely these smaller homes which could offer a more individual and homelike environment.

All recommendations in this report are already legislated in the Outcome Standards which are regularly inspected and enforced by Government Standards Monitoring Teams. Clearly there is no need for this further legislation.

It is a ploy under the guise of a Patients Bill of Rights to take away large amounts of money from the elderly. Mr Staples, Minister for Housing and Aged Care, will have achieved total control and regulation of all aspects of our industry if this legislation goes through. He totally ignored the huge amount of industry concern and submissions which were aroused by the draft report ``I'm Still an Individual''. The content of the final report clearly shows the whole exercise has been completed by people with virtually no understanding of the functioning of a nursing home.

We are concerned at the continuous putting down of the good work we do. Staff morale is at an all time low and current Federal policy makes it more and more difficult to attract or keep our caring workers. We ask you to support us in fighting this Bill in its present form with its horrendous legal and functioning problems.
Yours faithfully.
NAMBOUR NURSING HOME

I ask whether he is aware, specifically, that Mr Perkins has written:

Before the Adelaide meeting which passed resolutions against the chairman and the general manager I ensured that the Minister knew what was about to happen. He was really happy about this development.
I ask whether the Minister is further aware that Mr Perkins says:

My point is that I clearly recall informing Gerry Hand on the Saturday night a week before the Adelaide meeting of what resolutions were being proposed against Shirley McPherson and Mick O'Brien. I left him in no doubt that those resolutions would be passed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall the answer that I gave on 14 October-at least, I have had reason to refresh my memory as to the answer I gave. Of course, it was an answer given on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. As far as the letter supposedly or purportedly written by Mr Charles Perkins is concerned, quite clearly I have not had an opportunity to peruse that, though I have seen a newspaper article today which, I take it, draws on the contents of that letter. Senator Chaney indicated that he would be tabling that letter, but obviously I have not had a chance to peruse it.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the substance of the matters concerned, following the publication of the article in the Australian it has been a matter of importance to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to refresh his memory as to the sequence of events about that time. He has done so and has discussed the matter with the Prime Minister. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs gave a categorical personal assurance to the Prime Minister that the answer he gave in the House on 13 October and the answer given by the Minister representing him in the Senate-that is me-on 14 October are accurate. The Prime Minister has accepted that assurance.

The Minister has made the following points to the Prime Minister which established crucial inaccuracies in the article. I might mention some of them. Mr Perkins is quoted as saying that on the Saturday night a week before the meeting of the ADC he had a telephone conversation from Alice Springs with the Minister, who was at Marla Bore in South Australia. The article states that `that would be 1 October'. But the Minister was not even at Marla Bore on 1 October; he was in Melbourne. There was no telephone call from Mr Perkins to the Minister, who was attending various Victorian State election functions. If the Saturday night referred to was 8 October, again Mr Hand was not at Marla Bore but in Victoria. The Minister did travel to Marla Bore on Sunday, 2 October, but the Prime Minister has been informed by the Minister that he had no conversation with Mr Perkins. Mr Perkins did telephone Marla Bore but he spoke only to the then State Director for South Australia concerning transport arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't deserve to do this, Michael. They should not make you do these things. They should get Richo to do these things.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Chaney has asked a Minister whether he has misled the Senate. Senator Tate is entitled to be heard in silence without the clowns over there interrupting him.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Boswell, I would ask you not to interject.
—Mr President, perhaps there is a point of order. You might ask the Minister to withdraw the expression `clowns'.
—I withdraw.

—The article quotes Mr Perkins as saying that the conversation took place as the Minister was departing for Indulkana, but the Minister did not go to Indulkana. He visited a number of other places and Aboriginal communities in the days after leaving Marla Bore but did not speak to Mr Perkins at any of these places. Mr Perkins is also quoted as saying that he had conversations relating to the resolutions at the forthcoming ADC meeting with the Minister's Senior Private Secretary. The Minister informed the Prime Minister that that is not correct and that his Senior Private Secretary was travelling with him through South Australia. On the basis of these points made by the Minister to the Prime Minister, the Prime Minister can only suggest that Mr Perkins's recollections close to a year after the ADC meeting are faulty, whereas the Minister spoke in Parliament within days of the meeting. Accordingly, the Prime Minister has concluded that no case has been made that the Minister's answers in the Parliament have been other than accurate.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: What financial benefits are accrued to the Australian economy from foreign students studying in Australia and what is the breakdown of foreign exchange earnings from students in my home State of South Australia? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1987 the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) published a report on international trading services which, based on an assessment by Professor Goldring, showed that some $105m was earned in total from education services provided in Australia to foreigners. That was a 1983 estimate. EPAC estimated that each full fee paying student would contribute around $17,000 a year to export earnings other than fees and other expenses. A Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) study released more recently estimated that for the 1987 calendar year the earnings from fees and living expenses of overseas students was around $120m but Austrade, more recently again, with the assistance of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, surveyed Australian institutions which enrolled full fee paying overseas students in 1987. It concluded that earnings from tuition fees alone had risen by nearly 400 per cent from 1987 to the calendar year 1988. The BIE calculated that earnings would have at least doubled in 1988 to between $240m and $270m. That figure is expected to continue growing.

ANSWER.PARA: As at 30 June 1989 there were some 32,000 full fee paying overseas students in Australia, of whom 826 were enrolled in South Australia. In South Australia the figure has almost doubled from that of the previous year. Senator Foreman asked about South Australia in particular. I am advised that South Australia has an innovative approach to higher education marketing. The Office of Tertiary Education has established an overseas student promotional group which tends to market as a group rather than independently. It offers a complete spectrum of services from secondary to tertiary graduates. In South Australia, Flinders University, the South Australian Office of Tertiary Education, the Ministry of Education, the University of Adelaide, the South Australian Department of Technical and Further Education and the South Australian College of Advanced Education are involved in the marketing and promotion of courses offshore. Some have specific budgetary allocations. One institution sets that figure at 15 per cent of the full fee revenue.

The last part of Senator Foreman's question was: does the Government have plans to expand the service? It is certainly expected that earnings from these services will continue to grow in South Australia and elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to his concern expressed in February this year that Australia's low level of savings is exacerbating our foreign indebtedness and the submission by his Department's Bureau of Industry Economics calling for an inquiry into the level of national saving. Has the Minister been able to evaluate a recent proposal by the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies (AAPBS) which claims to be revenue neutral or, better still, revenue positive, yet encourages domestic savings by taxing at source all non-superannuation interest earnings at a rate of between 15 per cent and 20 per cent? Does the Minister agree that if the AAPBS proposal is realistically costed, its implementation will increase interest revenue collected by the Australian Taxation Office because the latest national account data shows total interest receipts by households at $17 billion while tax data shows that only $8 billion of interest was declared for tax purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question more appropriately directed to the Minister for Finance representing the Treasurer. It is a question of which I have had some short notice. I am endeavouring to obtain an answer from the Treasurer's office and I will supply that as soon as I possibly can.

ANSWER.PARA: I will comment on one or two points raised in the honourable senator's question. He drew a discrepancy between the alleged level of savings as estimated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and tax data which shows that only $8 billion of the $17 billion saved by households was declared for tax purposes. I just make the point that it is not easy to draw the conclusion from that that it is all because people are not paying tax on income from savings. The larger figure which appears in the national account includes partnerships, whereas the $8 billion does not. It includes children and a whole range of people who might otherwise not be eligible to pay tax. I am not sure that the honourable senator can draw the conclusion he appeared to draw in the third part of his question. The question requires a detailed evaluation of the proposal by the AAPBS. I will have that done and provide the honourable senator with an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen media reports of Mr Wilson Tuckey arguing that members of parliament should be paid more `so that ordinary Australians could aspire to represent their fellow citizens'? As Minister for Finance, has he been convinced that it would be fiscally responsible to increase substantially the pay for the position of Leader of the Opposition so as to provide incentivation for a more talented person to take on the job?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report along those lines in this morning's Australian Financial Review. It is impossible not to have some sympathy with those members of the Liberal Party who are somewhat aghast at the lack of talent, particularly that being displayed by their Leader. It goes even beyond the lack of talent to the lack of understanding of almost any policy of any consequence. Therefore, it is quite easy to understand why Mr Tuckey would want to see a person with more talent and competence or, may I say, even diligence occupying that position. The name most frequently floated as a non-parliamentary successor-that is, somebody who is not presently inside the Parliament and therefore apparently satisfied with the present remuneration-and the most frequent extraparliamentary pretender to the Liberal Party leadership appears to be unwilling to enter parliament at current pay rates.

ANSWER.PARA: The question then arises: How much more would he have to be paid before he was willing to enter Parliament? Some light may be shed on that by an article published in the Melbourne Herald on Monday, 26 June this year, when Terry McCrann estimated that it would cost Mr John Elliott roughly $44m net to enter Federal Parliament. That cost arises from Mr Elliott's 1c paid shares. Mr McCrann wrote:
You see Mr Elliott got rather too ambitious back in 1987-or rather the Board felt he needed a lot of incentivising. For it-
that is, the Board-
issued . . . 1 cent paid shares before the crash and they were issued at a price of $5.64. So Mr Elliott still has another $5.63 to pay on them.

There were about 15 million of those shares, so that contingent liability amounts to nearly $85m gross. Of course, the shares had a market value at the time leaving a net liability of the order of $44m. That still applies. At today's Elders share price of $3, the on call net liability--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney should declare his self-interest.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I was asked by Senator Ray to declare my interest. I think that I have the same interest as does every other member of parliament in getting a few questions asked and answered in this place. I suggest that the Minister is ranging extremely widely over this question. He should be pulled up on the ground of relevance and asked to sit down.

—Order! Senator Walsh, you were asked a question about the remuneration of parliamentarians. At the moment I am having some difficulty in trying to work out the ministerial responsibility for the answer.

—Mr President, I certainly have some ministerial responsibility because I have some responsibility for all Commonwealth Government expenditure. I was pointing out the size of the incentives that would have to be offered to induce some people into Parliament who some members of the Liberal Party clearly believe would be an asset to the Parliament, particularly their front bench and the leadership. As Mr McCrann points out, in the case of the person most frequently quoted, the upfront payment-if I could put it that way-that would be required appears to be at least of the order of $40m. That is what it would cost Mr Elliott to enter Parliament unless, of course, as I suggested yesterday, he were to flog off that contingent liability to a corporation and thereby ensure that the ordinary shareholders of Elders, who really put in the $40m in the first place, would never get it back.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, refers also to Mr Charles Perkins's letter which states quite clearly that Mr Hand had prior knowledge that a resolution would be carried at the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) meeting in Adelaide against Mrs Shirley McPherson, Chairman of the ADC, and Mr Mick O'Brien, General Manager of the ADC. TALK.START.PARA: —With due respect to Senator Boswell, I find it extraordinary that he should ask that question in light of the first answer I gave, which clearly indicated that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs held discussions this morning in relation precisely to the allegations made in the article in the Australian newspaper. —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister suggesting that Mr Perkins is a liar?

—Neither I nor the Prime Minister has made that assertion. —I refer the Minister for Finance to comments made yesterday in the Senate by Senator Knowles which were highly critical of the assets test on pensions. Is the Government planning to remove the assets test in the light of Senator Knowles's comments? What would be the cost of removing the assets test?
—What did I say?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles wants to know what she said. I can satisfy that request. Her exact words were:

ANSWER.PARA: When the Government looks at the effect of the assets test and many other measures that it has taken it will see that many more pensioners are in dire financial straits than there were some years ago.

In making that statement she has entered some data free area. The facts are that 64 per cent of all people of pensionable age receive a full pension; that is, their non-pension income is within the free area and is not counted for income test purposes. Principally and overwhelmingly, what matters to these people is the size of the pension and, a bit at the margin, the size of the free area. For those people to whom the size of the pension is the critical factor, it should be noted that in March 1983 the standard pension and equivalent payments stood at less than 23 per cent of average weekly earnings. This year they will rise, unequivocally, to above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In addition, there have been very substantial increases in the rent allowance for pensioners who have to pay private rent-an increase in real terms of some 74 per cent and, in those cases where pensioners have dependent children, a real increase of some 39 per cent. I made a speech last week which included this and a number of other facts, a copy of which I will consider sending to Senator Knowles so that she can revise her knowledge of this matter.

I was also asked what it would cost to abolish the assets test. It is possible to come up with different figures, depending on what assumptions one wishes to use. But on any reasonable assessment, the cost of abolishing the assets test would be at least $600m a year. If the proportion of people of pensionable age were still the same today as it was when the assets test was introduced and other things had remained equal, it would cost an extra $600m a year to abolish the assets test. I suggest that the actual cost, had that change not been made in 1984, would have been significantly higher because there was a clear rising trend among the people of pensionable age to qualify for pensions. In other words, people of that age group, in the absence of an assets test but with an income test, were changing their assets from income earning assets to assets which accrued capital gains. Undoubtedly, that process would have gone on had it not been for the changes that were made in 1984. So it is $600m plus. It is difficult to say how big the plus is, but it could well be another $700m, bringing the total cost of Senator Knowles's proposition up to around $1 billion a year.

Senator Knowles was elected in 1984 when about the only clear policy the Opposition seemed to have was Mr Peacock's populist policy of abolishing the assets test. However, it appears that even Mr Peacock has dropped that one now. If he has not done that, I would appreciate advice from the Opposition that Mr Peacock still intends to abolish the assets test. I would ask how the Opposition reconciles that with the calls from just about everybody else on the Opposition front bench for more targeted welfare expenditure.

—I do not think Senator Messner used the word `compensation' in the initial part of his question. I do not see any reason to change what I said yesterday. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and refers to genetic engineering. Is it true that Australian law does not prevent the patenting of any genetic material, plant or animal, including human, and/or the plants or animals in which that genetic material has been placed? Does the Government encourage the patenting of genetic material where that appears profitable? Is it therefore true that Australian law allows, and the Government would encourage, the patenting of animals including animals containing any number of human genes? Does the Government have reservations about this imminent possibility and does it intend to legislate in this area before the technology is applied?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave an answer to a similar question from Senator Powell on 30 November 1988. I said that the usual requirements of the Patents Act apply for applications for patents in respect of animals. I refer Senator Coulter to that answer and to the further information, particularly the last paragraphs which I had incorporated in Hansard at the time. The same answer applies to the patenting of any genetic material, plant or animal, including human, and/or the plants or animals in which that genetic material has been placed. I repeat that the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office would refuse any patent application for a human being.

ANSWER.PARA: As to encouraging the patenting of genetic material or plants or animals, the Government encourages the development of genetic engineering just as it encourages the development of other technologies generally in Australia. The patent system serves to encourage inventions and technological developments of all kinds and the transfer of technology between Australia and other countries. The Government encourages the use of that system where this is considered appropriate by inventors. There is nothing in the patenting of genetic material per se that is objectionable but there may be specific instances which could be inherently objectionable. The Patents Office has and should have a neutral role in this regard. The Commissioner of Patents can refuse to grant a patent on an invention where the use of the invention would be contrary to law. This would clearly be the case if the invention in question were a human being.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for that reply. I disagree with him; I do find the patenting of genetic material objectionable. The Minister has indicated that animals, including animals containing human genes, would be patentable. By what criterion would the Patents Office judge when sufficient human genes were included in that animal to make that animal not patentable? Should not that be defined in some way?
—I would assume that was a matter for the discretion of the Patents Office which is, of course, expert in these matters.
—But it is not expert in that question.

—Perhaps not, but are politicians? This is the point I am coming to in the rest of my answer. I do not know whether we can legislate to define the limits of the appropriate patent request. The Government receives advice on these matters from several bodies. We have not yet received advice in favour of legislation of that kind.

—Mr President, have you seen the report in yesterday's Canberra Times dealing with the appointment of a person to the Senior Executive Service (SES) position of Manager of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO)? Is it true that a duly appointed selection committee of SES equivalent officers interviewed candidates for this important position and did not recommend the appointment of the person who, it appears, has now been appointed? Is it true that unlike Commonwealth departments, where the recommendations are made to the permanent head, recommendations by selection committees for parliamentary officer positions such as this one are made to the Presiding Officers of the Parliament, who make the final decision? Can you tell the Senate why you decided to ignore the recommendation of the selection committee and, having so rejected, not to readvertise the position? Is the person you have appointed your Private Secretary, who has, if anything, a limited knowledge of or background in computing or information systems? Does this mean that the merit principle does not apply to the Parliamentary Information Systems Office?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to all honourable senators that the position of Manager of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office was advertised extensively in June this year. The selection committee interviewed a number of applicants and identified four people as being suitable for appointment. The committee also recommended a candidate for appointment. The Speaker and I reviewed the recommendation in the light of what we believed were in the best interests of senators and members and the delivery of information system services to them. We listed these concerns in detail to the Acting Parliamentary Librarian and asked him to make a further recommendation. This was done. We concurred with his recommendation and appointed Mr Robert Walsh, a senior parliamentary officer, to the position.

INTERJECT.PARA: I must say to all honourable senators that I have every confidence that Mr Walsh will provide the leadership and management which has been lacking in PISO in recent times. I am certain that the delivery of information system services to senators and members will be enhanced by the appointment of Mr Walsh as Manager and that PISO will be given the strong leadership and accountability it needs in the consolidation stage on which it is about to embark.

I also point out to honourable senators that when the selection committee gives a list of people to the Speaker or me, they are all considered to be worthy of appointment and the final decision depends on the Speaker and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did ask why the person nominated was rejected. I also ask whether the Parliamentary Information Systems Office has currently, or is likely to obtain in the future, the technical capacity to hack into the private word processing databanks and records of senators? Does this not make the position more sensitive?

—I will not use this chamber to talk about what I consider to be the merits or demerits of a particular candidate. I resent the implication in the second part of Senator Bishop's question. The weakness that I believe was occurring in PISO was that it lacked a managerial head and had too many technical people. That is the main reason for the appointment which was made.

—Has the Minister for Resources received reports of complaints by farmers' organisations concerning the possibility of the importation of Canadian pig meat which, it is suggested, could bring transmissible gastroenteritis into Australia? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government is entertaining a proposal to import pig meat from Canada and whether the pig meat is infected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is entertaining the question of admitting uncooked Canadian pig meat to the Australian market, although it has not at this point made a decision as to whether it will do so or not. I am aware, as Senator Giles has suggested, of industry concern about this. I suggest, though, that the industry concern that is currently being expressed is premature. The industry has been consulted quite extensively and the basis upon which the Government will make any decision relies on three matters: first, the risk of entry of disease with uncooked Canadian pig meat; second, the cost of the disease to the Australian industry should it become established; and, third, the commercial impact of imports on the domestic industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The risk of disease being transmitted has been assessed scientifically at one in three million on the worst case scenario. I do not think that goes to what would then happen if a disease beat those odds and became established. That issue is under further scientific scrutiny, and when the results are in we will turn our minds to it.

The decision will be made entirely and utterly on quarantine grounds and not on the grounds of any concerns about competition in the trade or trade-based concerns. I say that because Australia has been very active in the present General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Uruguay Round of trade negotiations in pushing for the reduction of tariffs and non-tariff barriers. If any trade-based decision were made we would be held up as an example of the type of thing we have been opposing in international forums.

I confirm that the decision is being entertained. It has not been made yet. Consultations have been entered into and scientific probability is being assessed. There are further assessments to be made and the decision will be made in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SAND MINING LEASES ON FRASER ISLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is it possible or likely that sand mining will resume on Fraser Island off the Queensland coast? What information can the Minister provide in regard to this subject? What action has the Queensland Government taken regarding mining leases on Fraser Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question was: Is it possible that there will be sand mining on Fraser Island? The direct answer to that question is: not while there is a Labor Government in Canberra. Whether there would be sand mining if a Liberal-National Party coalition government came to power is a question that could be answered in the affirmative. Yes, there would be.
—On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is, I am sure, out of order. In any event, he is clearly misquoting the policy position of the Opposition. He should be called to order and shut up.
—He is just lying.
—Order! Senator Puplick, I ask you to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—Thank you, Mr President. I base those remarks on the fact that early in August the Opposition released its environment policy, in which it pledged itself to no sand mining on Fraser Island. Doubtless that is why Senator Puplick is so exercised on this subject. Shortly afterwards, the Opposition released its policy on resource and energy development, saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We will abolish all export controls on the minerals and metals sector including those applicable to iron ore. The only exception to this being uranium as specified in section 9.

In the absence of export controls there would be no mechanism through which the Federal Government would be able to prevent the product of sand mining on Fraser Island being exported. Thus, it would lack the power to prevent what the Queensland Government has done since 1987 in renewing the leases for sand mining on Fraser Island. We have an obvious commitment from the Queensland Government in that, despite the fact that there was no public consultation, and despite the fact that compensation was paid after the Fraser Government ban on sand mining on Fraser Island, it reissued the mining leases in 1987. If the Opposition's resource and minerals policy were to be implemented there would be no controls over the export of that mining output. Thus I can answer the question from Senator Burns by saying that if there was a coalition government there would certainly be export of mineral sands from the Fraser Island mining development.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the announcement by Mr Kerin that the Government agreed to lower the floor price of uranium by $US5 a pound for uranium yellowcake contracts between the Ranger mine and the Japanese and Swedish utilities. Why does the Government persist with this useless bureaucratic charade when everyone-the Government, the sellers and the buyers-knows that an announced floor price is also the ceiling price? Is the Government seriously saying that before an approval is given it must be satisfied that prices achieved are comparable with those achieved by others in the market? If this is so, how on earth will markets ever be captured from our overseas competitors? Does this mean that the Government feels it has some obligation to Canada to ensure that Australia's share of the world market will be fixed at 10 per cent with Canada at 30 per cent?

—There is a lot of rhetoric and assumption in that question. Indeed, in the eyes of the Government the last part is reprehensible. There is no deal between this Government and the Government of Canada about shares of the uranium market. Anyone proposing that is venturing on a preposterous expedition. The Government has, in view of a settlement between Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) and its two shareholder customers, approved a floor price of $US26 a pound. Other settlements are expected to be finalised shortly. The total settlements include about half the current uranium exports. In the circumstances of those negotiations, the floor price of $US26 a pound was considered appropriate. Senator Parer asked why we maintain a floor price. We do so quite obviously in order to try to maintain a situation in which the best possible return is achieved for the uranium traded out of Australia.
—Why don't you have export controls as you do for coal?

—We do have export controls on coal. I was just about to move to that. In the past there have been expressions of concern by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy about negotiated coal prices which have resulted in those prices being renegotiated at a higher rate, thus achieving a better return for the people of Australia. The coal mining companies have also benefited from that. This is not an inappropriate parallel to draw in the case of uranium floor prices. I reject the propositions that we are beholden to either ERA or the Canadian Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is this Government so stupid that it does not realise that if one needs to be satisfied-I am referring to the press statement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy-that prices are to be `comparable with those being received by others in the market', presumably overseas competitors, we will never ever be able to increase the size of our market? Does the Minister think they buy from us because they like us?

—No, but I think price is an element of why they buy, as is the cost of transporting the commodity to the consumer, the reliability of supply from the country of origin and the quality of the ore concerned. Simply to fix on price as being the sole arbiter of purchase is to take too narrow and too insensitive a focus. All the other elements are factors in the negotiating process. I know that Senator Parer realises this, because he is smiling. He has been associated with coal negotiations in the past and he knows how silly the proposition he has just put is.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's reaction to the recent unsuccessful Cambodian peace negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in Paris last week, the outcome of the conference on Cambodia was disappointing and depressing in so far as it did fail to achieve its objective of reaching a comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian problem. The inability of the Cambodian parties themselves to reach agreement on power sharing was the principal stumbling block to achieving that comprehensive settlement. Nevertheless, it has to be said that, even bearing in mind that failure to reach the principal objective of achieving a comprehensive settlement here and now, the conference was not by any means a complete failure. Considerable work was done over the course of the last months in the various committees that were established in that conference to identify mandates for any international control mechanism that might be established, to establish procedures for a ceasefire, to identify international guarantees for the sovereignty, independence, neutrality and territorial integrity of Cambodia, to identify conditions conducive to the return of refugees and displaced persons and to identify the principles that should govern post-settlement reconstruction assistance. I should say that those reconstruction principles were unanimously agreed in the committee that was jointly chaired by Australia and Japan.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, the conference explicitly resolved that it not be wound up at the end of last week but that the co-chairmen-the foreign ministers of France and Indonesia-should hold consultations within the next six months on reconvening the conference when conditions seem more propitious. The co-chairmen have also been given continuing authority to facilitate discussions between the various parties and to reconvene committees as appropriate in the meantime.

Australia played a very active role throughout the conference, putting very strongly the view that it was important to maintain the momentum of the conference process in order to reassure the Cambodian parties of the commitment of the international community to a comprehensive settlement, to keep focusing on confidence building measures, including measures involving further work on the structure and role of the proposed international control mechanism, and to design such measures to help move the Cambodian parties to the point of willingness to make the necessary compromises with each other that they are manifestly unprepared to at the moment.

We share the widespread concern that there will be an intensification of fighting in Cambodia following the failure of the various factions to reach agreement. That concern lends a great deal of urgency to the need for all parties to redouble their efforts to achieve a Cambodian settlement. We will continue to lend our national support to such efforts and to maintain support for strategies which maintain pressure on all of the parties, both internal and external, that have the capacity to influence a final settlement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of days ago Senator Boswell asked me a question about imports of canned pineapples and what I intended to do about that matter. It had been reported in the press that the Australian pineapple processing industry was concerned at processed pineapple imports from developing countries. Canned pineapple imports in 1988-89 were 10.4 million litres valued at $6.7m. Imports increased 30 per cent in volume and 21 per cent in value compared with the position in 1987-88. In the same year, 1987-88, total sales were valued at $183m and exports from Australia were valued at $18.8m-about three times the value of imports.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian pineapples are processed at the Golden Circle Cannery at Northgate in Brisbane where production is predominantly of pineapple products. Based on 1987-88 canned pineapple production, imports represented only about 13 per cent of the domestic market. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare entitled Animal Experimentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Animal experimentation is the fourth report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

At the beginning of the inquiry into animal welfare, the Committee decided to divide its reference into discrete areas. It has already reported on live sheep exports; dolphins and whales in captivity and kangaroos. A report on sheep husbandry, the Committee's fifth report, will be tabled in a few weeks. The Committee is conducting hearings on intensive animal industries and on the racing industry.

Opposition to animal experimentation has a long history, going back 200 years or more in Britain. During the resurgence of interest in animal welfare in the mid 1970's, it was one of the first areas on which attention was focussed by the animal welfare movement.

The movement in Australia generally opposes the use of animals in experiments. Some parts of the movement are implacable in their opposition and advocate an immediate ban on it. Some animal welfare organisations see the abolition of animal experimentation as a long-term goal and, in the meantime, are trying to improve animal welfare by reforming the system.

The animal welfare movement questioned both the ethics and the efficacy of conducting animal experimentation in biomedical and other research. On the other hand, the scientific community pointed to many benefits for humans and animals which have been derived from animal-based research. It added that cures for many of the current scourges for which there is little or no treatment will depend on experiments on animals.

The Committee considered carefully the ethics of animal experimentation. It was not convinced that, on ethical grounds, there is justification for banning experiments on animals, as advocated by some animal welfare organisations. However, as sentient beings, animals need to be treated with respect.
The Committee took considerable evidence on the efficacy of animal experimentation. The evidence and the scientific literature clearly demonstrated the value of animal experimentation.

Having said that, the Committee notes that animal experimentation is not the panacea for all the ills of humans and animals. Many diseases are caused or worsened by environmental conditions and lifestyles. Their treatment is often more in our own hands rather than in biomedical research.

The Committee supports the continuation of animal experimentation, provided that every effort is made to find alternatives; including the reduction in and replacement of the use of animals, and the refinement of experimental design to reduce the pain and distress.

The Committee notes that little research has been done in Australia to find alternatives to the use of animals in Australia. Funding of research into alternatives has been given a low priority by funding bodies. Most experimenters have been reluctant to venture into this area because of the difficulty in securing funding.

Consequently, the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government establish a separate fund for research into the use of alternatives to animal experimentation and that grants be disbursed from the fund by a board composed of representatives of the scientific community, animal welfare organisations, the Australian Council for the Care of Animals in Research and Teaching and government authorities.

The use of animals in psychological experiments was strongly criticised by animal welfare organisations. The Committee's attention was drawn to psychological experiments conducted on animals in Australia and overseas which caused significant distress to the animals involved.

Some experiments in psychology overlap with other disciplines, such as physiology. It is not always easy to define clearly what is a psychological experiment. There also seems to be a greater awareness among scientists that some types of psychological experiments are unacceptable to the public or are no longer regarded as necessary from a scientific point of view. Consequently, the Committee does not believe a statutory ban on psychological experiments to be appropriate. However, the Committee believes that ethics committees should scrutinise protocols for psychological experiments with great care.

With regard to experiments on wildlife, the Committee believes that endangered species should only be subject to experiments which are designed to conserve that species. For other wildlife species, purpose-bred animals should be used wherever possible. Where this is not possible, ethics committees must ensure that the scientific merit and value justify the use of such animals.

The use of toxicological tests such as the LD50 and the Draize tests has evoked widespread criticism. Neither test has been used much in Australia and steps have been taken in some States to reduce their use even further. The classical LD50 test is no longer required for drug evaluation by Australian authorities. The Committee recommends a ban on both the classical LD50 and the Draize tests.

The Committee visited animal houses in a number of institutions to inspect the standard of facilities. Conditions in these animal houses varied from good to very bad. Animal houses have traditionally been given low priority in institutional budgets. Consequently, many animal houses need renovation and new equipment. It was pleasing therefore, that during the course of the inquiry the Committee was informed of the improvement of facilities or the construction of new animal houses at a number of universities.

High standard animal house facilities are important not just for animal welfare but also for obtaining reproducible scientific data derived from experiments on animals. The effects of environmental variables on animals have ramifications for research. Each variable might produce a biological response which could affect experimental data. This could jeopardise the outcome of scientific projects and waste valuable resources.

The breeding of animals for use in experiments has always been decentralised, except in Perth where the Animal Resources Centre provides most of the animals needed by Western Australian institutions. Decentralisation has led to a large number of animal houses vying for scarce resources, diseconomies of scale in production, inefficiencies and inadequate staffing structures.

The Committee believes that a rationalisation of breeding units is essential to provide high quality animals efficiently within available resources. There should be no more than four or five major breeding units to serve all institutions around the country. It would still be possible for institutions to breed small numbers of specific strains of a species, something which would not be cost-effective for a major breeding unit to do. Such a rationalisation in the number of breeding units is probably inevitable, but the Committee believes that a planned contraction would serve the scientific community better.
The use of animals obtained from pounds is a controversial issue in Australia and overseas. It is permitted in all States except in South Australia.

The Committee concludes that dogs from pounds may be used in experiments provided that where registered dogs are surrendered to pounds, their owners give written consent to their use by institutions. The Committee accepts the argument that if a dog is used in an experiment from which it will not recover consciousness, there is no difference between euthanasia in a pound and destruction at an institution. If by the use of pound animals, which will be destroyed anyway, there is a reduction in the destruction of purpose-bred animals, then animal welfare is enhanced overall.

There is a need to improve training of both animal house staff and experiments. The Committee believes that all animal house staff should have relevant technical qualifications or be enrolled in appropriate TAFE courses. Although most institutions have policies supporting the need for qualified technical staff, financial constraints have made attendance at TAFE courses impossible for some animal attendants. The Committee does not believe that financial stringency should prevent the training of animal house staff. It recommends that all unqualified staff be required to undertake technical training courses in animal care at TAFE colleges.

The Committee also draws attention to the lack of training available for experimenters in Australia. The need for training of experimenters is becoming more widely acknowledged, both in Australia and overseas. At present, most young experimenters learn experimental techniques and associated requirements from their supervisors. This is not entirely satisfactory as bad habits and out-of-date knowledge might be passed on to the young experimenters. There is also a need for experimenters to keep abreast of new developments in laboratory animal science, both to improve animal welfare and scientific procedures. The Committee supports a proposal for a course in laboratory animal science at the University of Sydney and recommends that funds be made available for its establishment.
The Committee also recommends that funds be made available to establish a chair in animal welfare and behaviour at the University of Queensland.

The Committee welcomes the establishment of the Australian Council for the Care of Animals in research and Teaching (ACCART). ACCART is an independent resource and information centre. It has already published a newsletter which has received international acclaim and is in the process of publishing a number of monographs. ACCART will also provide a forum for Australian and overseas experts to focus attention on a range of animal experimentation matters. Through seminars and conferences, run either by ACCART itself or in association with specialist bodies, complicated or controversial issues can be discussed to enable experimenters to keep abreast of developments in these fields.

In the final four chapters of the report, the Committee discusses the structure of animal welfare administration in Australia and the structure for the administration and control of animal experimentation. The two are inextricably linked and the administration of animal experimentation needs to be seen in the wider context of the administrative structure for animal welfare.

Under the Commonwealth Constitution, animal welfare is mainly a State responsibility. Before 1985, the State Governments played a low-key role in animal welfare. From that year, the States began to take a more active role. Legislation in three States-New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia-was upgraded in 1985 and 1986. All three States appointed animal welfare advisory councils, whose membership covered all major interests in animal welfare. This opened the way to a more participative approach to the administration of animal welfare.

Two other governments have moved to upgrade relevant legislation. The Queensland government advertised for written submissions early this year for a review of its animal protection legislation. A review of legislation in the Australian Capital Territory was completed early this year.

The Committee recommends that all States and Territories upgrade prevention of cruelty to animals legislation, appoint animal welfare advisory councils and establish government animal welfare units to administer the legislation, along the lines of the three States which have already done this.

The Committee supports the idea of the formation of a council of Commonwealth, State and Territory ministers responsible for animal welfare, once all States and Territories have undertaken the recommended reforms. The Joint Animal Welfare Council should form the standing committee of officials to support the ministerial council.

Although the Committee sees the need for the Commonwealth Government to have an animal welfare advisory council to advise it on animal welfare matters for which it has responsibility, the Committee does not support the proposed national consultative committee which is to be an advisory body to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Committee believes that it is inappropriate for some State Government representatives to be on an advisory body to a Commonwealth minister when responsibility for much of animal welfare is a State responsibility and the States involved have their own advisory committees.

Before 1985, there was, in effect, a self-regulatory system operating for the administration of animal experimentation. Although funding bodies, such as the National Health and Medical Research Council, required recipients of grants to comply with the `Code of practice for the care and use of animals for experimental purposes', there was no monitoring to ensure that compliance was achieved.

With the upgrading of legislation in three States in 1985 and 1986, government controls were imposed on animal experimentation, including the licensing of experiments and/or institutions, the mandatory appointment of ethics committees, the appointment of government inspectors and the incorporation of a code of practice into regulations.

This approach by the three States has often been called `enforced self-regulation'. It allows experiments to assume primary responsibility for the conduct of animal experimentation and the care of animals used in experiments. The institutional ethics committees are given the main supervisory role within a legislative framework. Through licensing, accreditation and monitoring by inspectors, the government ensures that the experiments and ethics committees are fulfilling their responsibilities.
The Committee supports the general approach taken by the three States and recommends that the other States and Territories adopt a similar approach to the control of animal experimentation.

The Committee believes that the State and Territory Governments should control animal experimentation and monitor compliance with the code of practice. It is not the role of funding bodies to undertake this function. Funding bodies are not equipped to monitor compliance and their scarce resources are better used in funding research. State and Territory governments have both the responsibility and the means to maintain control of animal experimentation.

There has been some dispute between the CSIRO and a State Government as to whether Commonwealth experimenters are subject to State laws dealing with animal experimentation. To avoid further disputes and to enable organisations such as the CSIRO to promote uniform standards and rules throughout all their offices in different States, the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth enact legislation to cover all Commonwealth employees who conduct animal experimentation. The Committee also recommends the appointment of an inter-departmental committee to co-ordinate and oversee animal experimentation in Commonwealth institutions.

The Committee addressed several matters in the final chapter of the report relating to the code of practice and ethics committees. In particular, it recommends that future revisions of the Code of Practice be carried out by a national conference consisting of representatives of governments, institutions which conduct animal experimentation, experimenters, animal house staff, specialist societies, animal welfare organisations, educational organisations and funding bodies and that final approval for those revisions be given by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments which include the Code of Practice in regulations.
I commend the report to the Senate.
