We are asking: Do we understand the rhetoric of the Government? Do we understand correctly from what has been said by Government spokespeople on various occasions that it would be the intention of the Government-quite apart from whether there is an inhibition or a capacity-that the grants which hitherto have been made as section 96 grants would generally be made hereafter as grants by ATSIC for the States? That is the answer we are seeking. I understand there is no inhibition but we want to know whether it is the intention of the legislation that that should happen.

—I believe it is the intention of the legislation to allow for that to happen. I cannot absolutely predict whether it will in any particular instance, but clearly, if the agreements can be reached between ATSIC and the States, that mechanism would be available to be used in relation to the grants which are presently generally made under the States grants assistance mechanisms.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. What he said underpins part of our reason for moving these amendments and for moving the next group of amendments. It may represent a difference of view across the chamber. There is another matter that I raised in the opening remarks on these amendments to which no response has been given; that is, the failure of the Government, on a matter of significance relating to the way in which grants are made to the States and Territories, to consult adequately with the States and the Northern Territory on this clause and on other clauses which relate to their potential funding. I reminded the Minister that many of the States and Territories have been unhappy about that failure to consult. I remind him further that the matter was raised a little over a year ago, I think at a meeting of the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council by some of his State colleagues, who indicated that they were unhappy. That unhappiness is not acknowledged in the second reading speech, neither has there been any reasoned response to the concerns they expressed at that time. I believe that we need at least to acknowledge that the history as I have set it out is broadly correct. If it is not correct, I would like the Minister to set out the way the Government asserts it is not correct. Our State colleagues would very much like to see that response.

—Naturally, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has raised the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) proposals with all the State Ministers from time to time and with a number of State Premiers, I understand, in routine meetings. To be more specific, at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting in November 1988 the AAAC passed a resolution calling on the Minister to meet with State and Territory Ministers who wished to do so and to make available members of the ATSIC task force for discussions. The Minister indicated his willingness to meet the terms of this resolution. I have to tell Senator Baume that the response of the States has been somewhat half-hearted. I know that the Minister attempted to arrange further meetings with all State Ministers after the February AAAC meetings in Canberra on deaths in custody, but apparently without success. The Minister met with representatives of two States and a Territory-New South Wales, Western Australia and the Northern Territory-in Sydney on 27 April 1989. The Minister has made every attempt to fulfil the spirit of the resolution of the AAAC meeting in November 1988. So far he has not had the meetings with the State Ministers that we might have anticipated would flow from that resolution, but not through any fault of his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has just told us that the resolution at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council (AAAC) was actually moved in November 1988, and that fits in with what I said-that it was a year ago. It is now September. At that stage our State colleagues had not been consulted about clauses such as the ones before us, which are likely to affect their financial capacity very significantly. In fact, the resolution passed in November was an expression of distress and concern, and was preceded by quite angry expressions by State colleagues of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), including those from Labor States. That is what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to know not what has happened since the State Ministers faced up to the Federal Minister and told him that they were unhappy but what happened before that. Why was there no consultation with some of the other major players? Senator Boswell has already set out for this Committee on several occasions some of the very significant contributions which the States make to the advancement of Aboriginal welfare in this country. It is incredible that in a formal sense the State Ministers had to proceed to this resolution last November at the AAAC meeting, calling on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to consult with them. The fact is that there have been few consultations with the States since then. The Minister for Justice mentioned New South Wales, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. So the States of Queensland and South Australia-States with major Aboriginal populations-have still not had consultations with the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —At their doing.

—The Minister says it is at their doing. If the Government is going to make changes of this magnitude and bring in powers of this kind when, as I said yesterday, failure to act could result, if the Commission so wished, in the abolition of States grants payments, consultation with the States and the Territories is the least that should have occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition remains convinced that the amendments which we propose are necessary. I say again what I said to the Committee yesterday: if it were the view of the Committee that ATSIC should have the capacity to plan and make decisions about States grants and about relations with the States, at the very least those arrangements should then be given effect through the Minister on a government to government basis. I understand that it is not constitutionally required, but I think it is required as a matter of constitutional propriety-an entirely different matter, a matter of intergovernmental propriety. I say this through Senator Tate to Mr Hand with the best spirit in the world: it will otherwise be very hard to argue that we are not creating a black parliament within Australia, because the making of States grants is a parliamentary function. I ask only that if they are to be made they be made with some maintenance of Minister to Minister and government to government contacts. The Opposition presses its amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -Last night Senator Coulter quite correctly picked up a problem which would confront State departments of Aboriginal affairs. If I am not incorrect, we were seeking to find some common ground or a form of words that would allow these amendments to be carried. Senator Peter Baume proposed that, even if the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) were to make the allocations, those allocations of Commonwealth funding should go through the Federal Government to the State Minister. That is about where we were last night before the adjournment debate took place. I pointed out, and Senator Coulter picked it up, that if the Government were to allocate money only through ATSIC to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the down side would be that State governments that run effective, and in some cases very good, Aboriginal affairs departments would abdicate their responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs. They could well say, `The Constitution was amended in 1967 and Aboriginal affairs are now for the Federal Government to run'.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the people of Australia really knew they were giving that power to the Commonwealth. I think they voted on whether Aboriginal people should be allowed to vote. Any right-minded person could not but support that proposal. Now Aboriginal affairs have been handed over to the Commonwealth, but most State governments have stayed in the ring and have their own departments responsible for Aboriginal affairs. But some States are working only on the funding they are getting under section 96 grants. That is not the case with my State, as I said last night. It has allocated $38m of Queensland taxpayers' money to Aboriginal communities. We run a very grave danger of removing the power of State governments over Aboriginal affairs-and the States have developed great expertise over a number of years-if we allow these grants to be allocated from ATSIC to State governments. The Committee should not think that this provision will not be used as a tool to control State governments. Deals will be done-`We'll give you this if you do this'. Sovereign State governments will not put up with it. They will walk away from it. That is where we were last night. I think Senator Coulter had those fears. I think Senator Peter Baume is coming up with a form of words that will be acceptable to Senator Coulter. I do not know whether he has worked out those words yet, but perhaps we could start from there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Boswell indicated, last night we were discussing the fact that there is both an up side and a down side to what is included in clause 10 (2)(b). The Minister has indicated that it certainly is potentially possible for all grants eventually to be channelled through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). I suspect that that would happen over some years under circumstances in which ATSIC established that it was capable of doing that and that the consequences of the movement of funds through ATSIC to the States and Territories were in the interests of Aboriginal people. As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has pointed out, the actual grants of money to ATSIC will remain under the control of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I did not mention last night-and it is something that has concerned me in my State of South Australia-is that it seems as though the State Department of Aboriginal Affairs is moving more towards mainstreaming services to Aboriginal people, which is really running counter to the direction in which ATSIC is going. I understand that the same situation obtains in New South Wales, where the tendency at the State level has been to mainstream services to Aboriginal people. I suppose to some extent that will be a counterweight to the fears I expressed last night.

Another matter which is evident to me-and I was waiting until Senator Peter Baume had completed his questioning of the Minister on clause 10 (2)(b)-relates to clauses 10 (2) and 10 (3). Clause 10 (2)(c) states:
to enter into an agreement (other than an agreement referred to in paragraph (b)) with a State or Territory;

The only difference between paragraphs (b) and (c) is that (b) says that it is `an agreement for the payment of a grant' and (c) says `to enter into an agreement (other than an agreement referred to in paragraph (b))'. Presumably the agreement refers to an agreement which does not involve an agreement for the payment of a grant and is, therefore, an agreement in relation to something which does not involve money. Yet that particular matter is one on which the Government is choosing to impose an overview of the Minister. I am referring to clause 10 (3), which the Opposition is seeking to remove. It states:
The power of the Commission to enter into agreements of the kind referred to in paragraph (2)(c) shall not be exercised without the written approval of the Minister.

In line with what the Minister is saying, it seems to me that potentially he is seeking very wide powers for ATSIC-something which I am supporting. It is a little surprising that in those agreements in which grants are not involved, agreements of a different kind, the Government is seeking to have an overview by the Minister to the extent that those agreements can be entered into only with the written approval of the Minister. If the intention is to impose some sort of accountability, I could understand clause 10 (3) referring to clause 10 (2)(b). But, in fact, it does not. It refers to paragraph 10 (2)(c) where, as I read it, money is not involved. I would like the Minister's comment on why he sees subclause (3) as so essential if it is not a matter of financial accountability. If the Opposition is seeking to delete paragraph 10 (2)(c), why is it deleting subclause 10 (3)? Is it simply a consequence that if the clause to which it refers is deleted--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—So there is nothing further than that?
—It is consequential.

—I thank Senator Baume. If paragraph 10 (2) (c) stays in, I would like to know from the Minister what strong reason there is to keep subclause 10 (3) in if it is not financial and if it is not, therefore, a matter of accountability. What is the risk of the Commission entering into agreements without the written approval of the Minister?

—Senator Coulter is correct in reading clause 10 (2) (c) as having to do with agreements that do not involve the payment of a grant to a State. I am informed that there might be, for example, an agreement between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and a State government for the joint administration of housing loans, or some such thing, in which case the agreement would be entered into, but with that supervisory role of the Minister, as indicated in subclause 10 (3), in that his approval would be required. It is ultimately a question of accountability. The Opposition does not need a form of words in relation to paragraph 10 (2) (b) because, if we are correct that clause 55 is the basis of grants of an appropriation which would allow ATSIC to enter into an agreement for the payment of a grant to a State, the Estimates process and the whole Appropriations process would require, as we all know from Estimates committees, full responsibility to be taken for those appropriations. So paragraph 10 (2) (c) operates within a context where the approval of the Minister is required because of the need to ensure that the agreements between ATSIC and the States fall within a general program which is appropriate within our federal system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to ask Senator Coulter whether he would join the Opposition in supporting an amendment in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That while ATSIC might propose a States-grant type arrangement, the grant and any agreement should each be finalised by the Minister.

I think that would alleviate some of the problems that we will have from State governments as Federal moneys which were normally allocated through section 96 grants will now, under this legislation, go through ATSIC. Senator Coulter expressed fears last night which he referred to as the `down side' or the `flip side'. If an amendment of the sort that I have just proposed were accepted by the Australian Democrats, I think that would put a buffer in there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we would not accept that alternative amendment. It really does the same thing as the deletion of those clauses, so in effect its operation would be the same. Moreover, the ATSIC budget will come before the Minister and, through the Minister, back to the Parliament so that essentially the ability to make a bid for one of those grants to the State through the Budget process will be there and the overview will be in place, through the Parliament through the Budget process, although not specifically at the time the decision might be taken. Nonetheless, it will be competent for the Minister to say, `No, you cannot make that sort of grant'. So we do not find that alternative approach acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Page 12, paragraph 18 (1) (a), line 40, leave out the paragraph.
(15) Page 12, paragraph 18 (1) (b), line 41, leave out ``State, Territory and''.
(16) Page 13, after subclause 18 (3), add the following new subclause:
``(4) The Commission may recommend to the Minister that specified loans or grants of money should be made to:
(a) a State, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory; or
(b) a State or Territory body;
for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.''.

I remind the Committee that it is desirable to group the amendments wherever possible if we are to keep the debate within an orderly frame. These three amendments have been moved to clause 18 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. Clause 18 provides to the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission a capacity to make loans or grants of money on such terms and conditions as it determines. Subclause (1) specifies that it may do so to:
(a) the States and the Northern Territory;
(b) State, Territory and local government bodies;
(c) Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations; or
(d) any other incorporated bodies;
for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

Clause 18 has two other subclauses. I notice that the Opposition has a proposed amendment to subclause (2), which will be part of the Opposition's group 13 amendments. We are still on the group 3 amendments, so we will come back to that at a later stage. I just indicate that that is on the list.

Our third amendment proposes the addition of a new subclause (4). The first amendment proposed that we leave out clause 18 (1) (a) which seeks to give the Commission power to make, on such terms and conditions as it determines, loans or grants of money to the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. The Opposition has also moved an amendment to clause 18 (1) (b). We seek to leave out the words `State, Territory and' and retain the words `local government bodies' simpliciter. The third amendment in this group is the insertion of new proposed subclause (4), which would appear at the end of clause 18 on page 13. Proposed subclause (4) states:
The Commission may recommend to the Minister that specified loans or grants of money should be made to:
(a) a State, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory-
I interpolate here that we did not forget to include the Australian Capital Territory-
or
(b) a State or Territory body;
for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

First, I will talk to the structure of the amendments. It is not the intention of the Opposition, as the Committee will see if it looks at our amendments, that it should be impossible for loans or grants of money to made to a State, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory or a State or Territory body for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders. That is not and has never been the position of the Opposition. It is just that the mechanism that we propose in that subclause is the mechanism to which I have referred throughout the debate on the previous group 3 amendments. That principle is that the loans or grants should be made by the Minister. The Opposition has sought to insert subclause (4) to enable that to occur. We could then remove from clause 18 (1) (b) the references that I have mentioned and delete clause 18 (1) (a) because they will be subsumed within new subclause (4). I do not want anyone reading the amendments to imagine that we are trying to make it impossible for loans or grants of money to be made to a State, the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory. In fact, proposed new subclause (4) is designed to preserve the position of the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.

I reiterate that we base much of our argument on section 96 of the Constitution, which allows the Commonwealth to make grants to the States on such terms and conditions as the Parliament determines. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has made it clear in response to questions that this is the way that the Parliament so determines it shall be done, but the effect will be to provide to the new Commission a capacity to move into the place of government in making section 96 grants or the equivalent of grants. When we were discussing the previous clause, the Minister spoke about agreements. But I remind the Minister that this time we are talking about grants. This time the section 96 analogue is much more exact. It does not require the making of an agreement first. It simply empowers the new Commission to make loans or grants. So the situation here is much more analogous to the section 96 grants provided for by the Constitution. As we have said before, to go down this road, to give to the Commission a function which has previously for almost 90 years remained with the Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is where it should be.

—Senator Crichton-Browne says that that is where it should be. That is precisely the argument we are putting to the Committee. We believe that that is where the power should be. We believe that, in spite of what the Minister says about the preparation of Estimates and the examination by Estimates committees, the proper way for States grants legislation to be dealt with is the way in which we have traditionally dealt with it-that is, by means of a Bill for an Act that comes to this place and is debated and voted upon, like all other proposed Acts of Parliament.
—Section 96 was a deliberate inclusion in the Constitution.

—Senator Crichton-Browne says that section 96 was put into the Constitution quite deliberately. It is true that it does say `on such terms and conditions as the Parliament thinks fit'. Of course, that gives the Government a capacity to delegate that power to ATSIC. But I ask Senator Crichton-Browne, who comes from Western Australia: How will the Western Australian State Government regard such an arrangement and how will it feel about it when, instead of dealing government to government, it will be government to ATSIC?
—Much worse; it didn't even like section 96.

—I have to respond and say that as a Minister I had most trouble with the States of Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia. Of those three States, Western Australia was the most trouble. In fact, I seem to recall that a Western Australian Minister used to send angry telex messages to the Prime Minister once a week calling for my dismissal. I am not going to tell honourable senators who it was; they can guess.
—It was your own Party as well in government then.

—It was my own Party, but of the three States I have mentioned one had a National Party Government, one had a Labor Party Government and one had a Liberal Party Government. So my dislike for what they did was quite ecumenical, and the difficulties they made for me were, as it were, non-party political in their origin. They simply did not like to deal with Commonwealth government and we had different ideas about what the constitutional amendment of 1967 had meant. That has been a recurring problem. One of the States actually said that it meant that the Commonwealth had to do everything. We had to say, `No, it is a matter of conjoint powers in this area now'. We were told by the State that that was nonsense. A former State Premier, now serving in this Parliament-there is only one-once told me that the function of the States is always to take the socks off the Commonwealth. Having been a Commonwealth Minister, I have no doubt that he is correct.
—If he had gone through the Senate he would have the pants off you now.

—He tried. I was once asked in Western Australia how I dare seek to administer the Eastern Goldfields communities from Alice Springs. At that stage I was sick of it. I said to the relevant Minister that it was my department and that was how I chose to do it. That shut him up.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the amendments. In the previous group of amendments we were talking about the making of agreements. The Minister correctly pointed out that an agreement involved two parties, but this clause of the Bill is different. It is now talking about loans and grants. The section 96 analogy is quite appropriate. The amounts which are granted in these State grants will not now appear as appropriations in Appropriation Bill (No. 2). They will be voted by the Parliament as part of the funds of ATSIC. We do not yet know how those funds will be presented. The difference is a difference which every senator should appreciate. Our powers in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) differ markedly from our powers in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 2).

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. You wait until we get to the appropriations for the Department of the Senate.

—This question of which is the appropriate Bill in which matters should appear has concerned Senator Crichton-Browne in relation to the appropriations for the Parliament. I put to Senator Coulter and other members of the Committee that if we are unhappy with any elements in ATSIC's vote, and if that appears as part of Appropriation Bill (No. 1), all we can do from this place is make a request for an alteration. I remember that former Senator Sir Reginald Wright fought long and hard in this place for proper separation of items between Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). I put it to the Committee that one of the consequences of going down this track is that certain matters will be moved from Appropriation Bill (No. 2) to appear in the estimates of ATSIC's funds and as such will be much less amendable by the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the amendments. These amendments would require the Commission, if it decided it wanted to make a loan or a grant, to recommend to the Minister what grants or loans should be made to the States and Territories and it would then be for the Minister to arrange for the moneys concerned to be voted. That would occur through Appropriation Bill (No. 2). In that way the Parliament would have proper oversight over the moneys, as it has had for 89 years.

I come back to the other point that I made to the Minister earlier. As the Bill is drafted, the Commission is not obliged to make any grant or loan-not a single cent-to any State or Territory. It might well decide to do away with all the State grants going to Senator Coulter's State, to Senator Boswell's State or to Senator McKiernan's State. The Commission is not obliged to pay a single cent to any State or Territory. Under clause 10 it can negotiate agreements with the States. I agree; Senator Tate has made that clear. But refusal by a State to negotiate or accept ATSIC's terms could easily be met with a refusal to pay any money to the State in order to help its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens. The scope which that will provide for disruption to the Aboriginal programs for which a State has responsibility would be considerable.
For all those reasons the Opposition believes that the three amendments which it has proposed are reasonable and necessary. I commend them to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We return to the argument we had with the previous amendments-that is, we are going through a complete devolution of the power of the State governments. I support Senator Peter Baume because he has been a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He gave us some anecdotal evidence of his experiences when he was a Minister. We have to deal with facts. I come from a State that is very pro State rights, and I know that Senator Crichton-Browne represents such a State also. We face the problem that State governments which believe that they are doing an excellent job on Aboriginal affairs will be seen as absolutely downgraded by clause 18 (1). It refers to loans and grants for special purposes and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the Commission may, on such terms and conditions as it determines, make loans or grants of money to:
(a) the States and the Northern Territory;
(b) State, Territory and local government bodies . . .

.Community governments do get Federal allocations, so I suppose that clause 18 (1) (b) would be all right as far as local governments are concerned. But it is certainly an affront to the State governments that they will have to deal with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) rather than have ministerial contact. Again I say to Senator Coulter that it is not the State governments that will suffer. Ultimately, it is the Aboriginal people who will suffer as State governments move away from having departments of Aboriginal affairs.

Unfortunately, Senator Coulter missed going to Queensland. I would have been delighted if his time had allowed him to go to Queensland with the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs to see what the Queensland State Government has done for its Aboriginal people. Some of the members of the Committee from other States acknowledged privately-I do not expect them to do it publicly; these were members of a different political persuasion from mine-that the communities in Queensland were far better run and had better facilities than those in most of the other States.

I say to Senator Coulter with all the force I can muster that he is playing a very dangerous game. I cannot see anything wrong with the Federal Government under this legislation allocating its proportion of taxpayers' money through ATSIC. If that is what it wants to do that is fair enough. But surely we can come to some common ground in the interests of Aboriginal people that those allocations will be made on a government to government basis. It is not hard. It does not require an amendment. It does not require us to pull ATSIC to pieces.

Under the formal words that Senator Baume proposed in the previous amendments, the Commission will still be making the allocations to the various States but it will be doing it in the traditional way that this Parliament has followed for the last 89 years-that is, on a government to government basis. I know that when I go back to my home State and tell the Aboriginal affairs Minister that he is no longer to have any dealings with the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he will be absolutely horrified. His natural reaction will be to ask, `What do they expect from us? We have just given seven million acres to the Aboriginal people. We have given them all the communities and the islands. We have established local governments throughout these communities and given them the power to make their own decisions. While we are giving them the power to allow them to do this, we are being treated with absolute contempt by the Federal Parliament'. I have raised this matter before. I know the regard that the Australian Democrats hold State governments in, but it is not up to the Democrats to rewrite the Constitution. The fact is that State governments exist under the Constitution. Whether the Democrats want or have no regard for State governments is of no importance; the fact is that under the Constitution they have the power to exist. Senator Coulter has to recognise that-not from a party political point of view, but as a fact of life. They exist for the betterment of the Aboriginal and Islander people. Senator Coulter is ignoring these facts to the detriment of the people who will be terribly affected. I ask Senator Coulter to reconsider his attitude, particularly on this clause, to see whether he can find it in his heart to recognise that State governments exist and provide services and that those State and Territory government services will be reduced if we proceed down the course of taking the power to allocate funds away from the State governments and Ministers and giving it to ATSIC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Boswell has just said is a non sequitur because he is seeking to remove paragraphs (a) and (b) of clause 18 (1), which gives grants to the States, the Northern Territory and local government bodies. Clearly, the recognition that those bodies exist and have certain rights and powers is written into that clause. Senator Boswell has several times had a go at the Australian Democrats in relation to our attitude to State governments and States' rights. `States' rights' is a term much loved by the Federal Opposition. Quite a substantial body of legal opinion says that the constitutional position is that the States have those rights which have not yet been taken up by the Commonwealth. Certainly, our position is that in many areas the Commonwealth should exercise its powers far more widely than it has hitherto. We believe the Commonwealth has much wider powers, particularly in environmental protection. Indeed, we have urged the Federal Government to exercise its powers under section 51 (i) and section 51 (xx) of the Federal Constitution, the trade and commerce power and corporations power, to properly protect the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically on the matter of the States, we would prefer that government be much closer to the people and, as I believe is the fundamental position of the Labor Party, we would prefer much more powerful and larger regional governments and the Commonwealth Government, with the State governments disappearing altogether. That would be a much better administrative structure for Australia, and that is the position of the Democrats.

I would like the Minister's comment on the amendment proposed by the Opposition because it seems to me that clause 10, which we were debating earlier, allowed the Commission to enter into agreements to do certain things, and this is the complementary one which allows it specifically to do that, having entered into the agreement. That is the way I would read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It also allows them to make grants without an agreement. The loans would require an agreement, wouldn't they?

—It would seem to me that that reading of it is open to us, but it would be quite ridiculous to have the ability to enter into an agreement to make a grant and then not be able to proceed to make the grant, which would be the effect of deleting those clauses.
—Senator, read our proposed subclause (4). It puts the power back in a slightly different form.

—Certainly, but it then makes it subject to the Minister. As we have already not acceded to the Opposition's amendments to clause 10, it would leave the Commission with the ability to enter into agreements but not to honour those agreements. I concede that Senator Baume has a point in that in this case grants or loans could be made without prior agreement-that is certainly my reading of it-but I do not find that particularly objectionable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 18 epitomises all that I find objectionable about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill in the sense of the assumption of responsibility it takes unto itself. I have wider objections to it which go to the heart of the problem, that is, the Bill will do more to destroy the Aboriginal community, their well-being, future growth and development than anything else I can imagine. But as I said last time I spoke on this issue, as long as we have a Minister who is ideologically driven by a personal ambition to stamp his social mark on the Aboriginal community, I expect that we will be visited by other Bills like this in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill fundamentally dismantles the three tiers of government, their composition and their intrinsic relationship with each other. The Bill-naked, unclothed and in the light of day-fundamentally sets upon the community of Australia, black and white, a new political system, a parliament for Aboriginal people. That is the Minister's view of self-determination. As Senator Peter Baume said before, it will do anything but that because the people of the regions and the zones will end up representing absolutely nobody. Certainly, they will not be representing the people in the way in which they are used to being represented.

I was horrified to hear the Australian Democrats' spokesman, Senator Coulter, in his glib and predictable way, talk about States' rights. That is the indulgent form of the expression we hear these days from this new brand of politician. They should refer to States' responsibilities and the rights that accompany the responsibilities. To hear the Democrats say that the power of the States is that power which has not yet been assumed by the Commonwealth really sums up their attitude towards the federal system of government in Australia. It is summed up also by their policy, which talks about State boundaries being an accident of history and which says that they ought to be dissolved and replaced by local government regions. In other words, they propose doing away with the States. That is in their platform.

As the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, will know better than most, the Australian Democrats time after time have introduced into the Parliament legislation which fundamentally seeks to usurp the responsibilities and the role of the States. The legislation for uniform land rights for the Aboriginal community in Queensland, introduced by Senator Macklin in about 1982, is probably still sitting on the Notice Paper somewhere gathering dust, like most of the Democrats' decaying and failed proposals. It seems to me that the Democrats do not understand the history of Federation. They do not acknowledge that this creature of the Commonwealth Parliament was arrived at by agreement by our founding fathers through the imprimatur given to them by the various States-the founding States, the original States. The founding fathers were very clear and distinct in ensuring that the powers given under the Commonwealth were to be clear and defined and that residual power was to rest with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely; residual power?

—Every single power other than those given particularly and precisely to the Commonwealth in the Constitution. It was never intended that the insidious, pernicious intrusion into their rights by what some describe as the enlightened High Court of Australia would ever take the powers away to the extent it has because, of course, the Constitution would never have been consummated.

SPEECH.PARA: As a bit of political trivia for Senator Coulter, it was only as a result of the fact that we had so many eastern States goldmining prospectors in the western goldfields that Western Australia ended up voting for the Constitution. It was the eastern Staters who had planted themselves in Kalgoorlie and Coolgardie that swamped the positive and responsible reflex of traditional Western Australian people who in the end ensured that the Yes case was carried, notwithstanding the best endeavours of Lord Forrest in those days to persuade the local people it was right because he had been promised a side deal-and that was self-determination in Western Australia-by our dear father and mother country. That is how we got the Constitution. We got it no other way than by the collective wisdom of the various States coming together. These days some assume that all wisdom, knowledge and understanding flow from Canberra back to the States which have mendicant, subservient, second-class parliaments that really ought to deal with the inconsequential matters of life. Of course, the situation is anything but that.

This legislation tears at the very fabric of the three tiers of government in Australia. It seems to ignore the fact that local government, for instance-and it is a sin of not only this Bill but also successive governments-is a creature of State legislation. It ignores the intrinsic relationship between Commonwealth, State and local governments. It is totally inimical to good government in this country.

I have no doubt that the Bill will be divisive and destructive and will achieve absolutely no purpose other than to give a warm inner glow to those who believe that self-determination, whatever that means, is more important than the fundamentals that go to the well-being of the Aboriginal community. It is not without significance that the Government, supported ably by the Democrats, has directed all its energy into this legislation because it came to the conclusion at the end of the day that there were no politics in uniform land rights, notwithstanding the fact that they were fundamental to the platform of the Australian Labor Party when it was elected in 1983 and remain fundamental to the platform of the Democrats in 1989. They were also fundamental to the platform of the Labor Party in Western Australia when it was elected. Of course, it stepped back from the proposition.

I am only sorry that this Bill will not be thoroughly defeated, but I conclude by saying to Senator Coulter: let there be no secret about where the Democrats stand in respect to States. It is in their platform. Let there be no secret about where the Labor Party stands. The temporary Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in the Boyer lectures that he believed in the abolition of the States. This legislation will go a long way down the road to undermining the States' constitutional responsibility, to no good end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want particularly to get into the States rights argument and would not have done so had Senator Boswell not raised the issue. But I wish Senator Crichton-Browne had listened to what I said. I will repeat it.
—Don't; you will provoke me again.

—I will provoke Senator Crichton-Browne again if this provokes him. I said that there is a substantial body of legal opinion which says that the States have no rights other than the residual powers which the Commonwealth has not taken up. I am not legally trained and I am not in a position to comment on that legal opinion, but I have read substantial legal opinion which says just that. There is at least an answerable case in that respect. I object to the hidden agenda which lies behind what Senator Crichton-Browne said. He and his ilk are really on about dividing and ruling-keeping the States small and divided so that organisations which are substantial-the wealthy mates of people such as Senator Crichton-Browne-can go in and take-
—Give me names. Tell me who my friends are.

—Yes, I will give Senator Crichton-Browne a name. He specifically mentioned uniform land rights and the situation in Western Australia where, to quote his words, the Western Australian Government backed down on land rights. The reason for that was the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) ran a successful and very expensive advertising campaign to defeat land rights in Western Australia and politically the Government was forced to back down. That is precisely what Senator Crichton-Browne is on about. He is on about keeping the States in a situation where they are not strong enough because they can be struck off one against the other. That would not be possible if the Commonwealth Government were to exercise properly its powers in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we support, as Senator Crichton-Browne has said the Labor Party does, uniform land rights. Let us make no bones about the hidden agenda which Senator Crichton-Browne and people such as him have when he extols the virtues of so-called States rights. It is not States rights he is on about; it is protecting the powers of rich people who can then override the interests of the States, not only with respect to Aboriginal affairs but with respect to things such as petrochemical plants-major industrial developments-where one State will give in to a proposal rather than see it go to another State. We desperately need much stronger Commonwealth powers to be exercised in those areas. Let us not have too much more argument about States rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not take a point of order when Senator Coulter reflected upon my motives. I found his remarks inaccurate rather than offensive because I am not very often desperately hurt by the piercing shafts of the Australian Democrats. But at least I would like to have the record put right. To my knowledge, the Labor Party of Western Australia, whose platform called for uniform land rights, did not introduce land rights legislation into the State Parliament because the then Premier-some would say, perhaps unkindly, the now discredited then Premier-made a pragmatic political judgment that he was in the wrong canoe in the same way that he aborted his legislation in respect of electoral reform, over which the Hon. Arthur Tonkin, the then Minister responsible for electoral reform, resigned. I suppose Senator Coulter would blame the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) for that. The truth of the matter is that on both occasions the Premier put his nose to the wind and sniffed from whence it was coming. It was nothing to do with AMIC, mining companies or friends of friends; it was a political reality that when he did his polling he discovered he was on a loser. Always inclined to be a winner, he did not back bad causes. When he did back bad causes, he packed his bags and went to the Vatican.
—To Dublin.
—It was Dublin.
—I am sorry; that is right. He just goes to the Vatican for spiritual refreshment.
—He is Ambassador to the Holy See, but he is domiciled in Dublin.
—We are getting a little off the track.

—It is appropriate that the truth be found where it is, not in the perverted, distorted and confused mind of a Democrat. Land rights were not instituted in Western Australia, simply because there were no votes in it, Senator Coulter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a tremendous amount to say because I regard this small group of amendments as being consequential on the three amendments we have just voted down. They are really all part of a parcel and were grouped together originally by Senator Peter Baume. Since the Committee has voted down proposed amendments (11), (12) and (13), I think most of the arguments have already been heard at great length which would be appropriate to any discussion of amendments (14), (15) and (16).

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, the political fear expressed most eloquently by Senators Boswell and Crichton-Browne is that somehow-and I think Senator Crichton-Browne himself used the term-the responsibilities of the States, rather than their rights, will be diminished by the way in which this series of clauses in the Bill is put together. Once again, I remind the Committee that, if one looks at the objects clause of this legislation, one sees precisely that the intention of the Parliament is made clear: that whatever ATSIC may or may not do, it should not detract from the responsibilities-and that term is used in clause 3 (d)-of the State, Territory and local governments to provide services to their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. It would be very sad if the movement, as Senator Boswell has outlined, away from--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which clause is that?

—Clause 3 (d), the objects clause of the Bill. It would be very said if, as Senator Boswell indicates, States were to give up their responsibilities in this area because they thought that the Commonwealth should take an exclusive funding role for the provision of services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I do not see this particular provision as exacerbating the situation. Senator Boswell indicates that it is already under way in some States; that is unfortunately their political decision. I do not see that the mechanism provided here for ATSIC to make moneys available by agreement with the States need exacerbate that effect. In fact, it might lead to a cooperative and joint approach which can only be to the benefit of the Torres Strait Islander and Aboriginal peoples of Australia. It is the intention of the Government, obviously, to oppose these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not responded to a number of matters which I raised and to which the Opposition would like some response. However, may I begin by returning to the Minister's reference to clause 3 (d). The words he used came from the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: to ensure co-ordination in the formulation and implementation of policies affecting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments,
I note the words `Australian Capital Territory' have not been added there, and perhaps they need to be. The passage continues:
without detracting from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local governments to provide services to their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents.

I just note those words. In fact, that is not relevant. No-one is suggesting that this clause would, in some way, require the States to detract from the responsibilities of State governments to provide their own services. Senator Tate-That it would have that effect was Senator Boswell's theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would, if the States grants programs were unilaterally discontinued by ATSIC. I will suggest to the Minister how that might happen. ATSIC might well decide that the State of Tasmania received so much by way of States grants money, but it could be better applied if ATSIC spent it directly. ATSIC might make that decision and say that it was a proper exercise of its power. It might discontinue that money. If that happens, the programs in that State which are dependent upon States grants will be put in jeopardy. That is not inconsistent with the objects clause. That money has been provided to the State of Tasmania, as it were, in addition to money it might spend to discharge its own responsibilities as set out in that clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The points which I was making and to which I sought answers from the Minister remain unanswered. First of all, is it correct that, if this clause stood, moneys which are now provided for by way of States grants Bills and moneys which appear in Appropriation Bill (No. 2) will no longer do so? The Minister said in response to earlier questions, I think yesterday, that the moneys would appear in the ATSIC estimates and was asked whether they would not appear in Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I want that made clear because it has a consequence for the capacities of this chamber, because of other provisions in the Constitution with which the Minister is much more familiar than am I. That should at least be answered so it is on the record. A number of people will want to read the record, and we want a statement on the record here for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, okay.

—Further, I would like confirmation of our concern that, given a less advantageous scenario, clauses 10 and 18 together might well lead to a States grants program being discontinued, because there is nothing here to require ATSIC to continue with States grants programs. These are merely enabling clauses to provide ATSIC to do so if it wishes, but the programs, which have been very considerable over a number of years-perhaps 15 or 20-may well be discontinued by the Commission in the exercise of its powers and the pursuit of its functions. The concern has been expressed to us that the refusal by a State to negotiate the ATSIC terms could easily be met with a refusal to pay anything to that State.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point on which the Opposition would like some comment is this: Are we correct in assuming that this clause was not discussed with State and Territory Ministers prior to its appearance in the Parliament in the draft of the Bill last year, and that it was part of the material about which the Ministers expressed their concern at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting in November to which the Minister has already referred?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I did not respond to the first of the three questions. It is clear that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) appropriations will be a one-line appropriation item in Appropriation Bill (No. 1), that the estimates will come to the Estimates committee with explanatory notes and so on, and that there will be the usual discussion that accompanies that particular type of appropriation.
—That will be detailed, will it?
—They will be detailed estimates, of course.
—That means that the States grants have formerly appeared in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), does it?

—In so far as any of those States grants are, indeed, taken over, as it were, by ATSIC, they will now appear in the estimates relevant to Appropriation Bill (No. 1). But, as I say, it is not exhaustive and not exclusive. Some State grants could still be available under Appropriation Bill (No. 2). As to the second question--
—It has moved from Appropriation Bill (No. 2) to Appropriation Bill (No. 1)-from amendable to non-amendable.

—Senator Peter Baume is quite right-this is an enabling piece of legislation. It does not attempt to guarantee or to put particular grants to the States in place forever. The idea that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission would walk away from all these grants is somewhat far-fetched. Technically, in a legal sense, the States will be in as much or as little jeopardy or peril as they presently are as far as States grants are concerned. Obviously, whether they continue to be offered will depend on the will of the body bestowing the grants-the Government or the Commission. That will always be the case. Commonsense would indicate that those various grants to the States will continue, but of course not in an absolutely fixed form forever.

SPEECH.PARA: The third question related to consultations. I have already explained that I do not have a clear knowledge of the sorts of discussions that might or might not have taken place between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and the State Ministers up to the November Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting in 1988. The fact is that since that time some eight months have elapsed and the Minister has been willing to talk with State Ministers in regard to their concerns about ATSIC in the terms of the resolution passed at the meeting. He has continually sought meetings with those Ministers but has been able successfully to hold such meetings with only two States and one Territory. All discussions require two parties, and for one reason or another the other States have not thought it necessary to come forward and hold those discussions in the terms of that resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It emerges clearly from the explanation of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that the capacity of this Parliament to amend or to vary States grants in the Aboriginal area will be quite markedly reduced by the passage of this legislation in the form proposed. The Minister has said that it will not reduce our capacity to examine them by way of the Estimates process. That is not contested, but all senators know, and the Committee will be aware, that our capacity to amend anything in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is extremely limited. Further, I remind the Committee that this is the democratic parliamentary chamber of Australia-not the other place, which is always the executive chamber, always controlled by the government of the day. If there is to be any examination other than just an examination of a formal nature such as occurs in the other place with set piece speeches and predictable votes, it will take place in the parliamentary chamber-and that is the Australian Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are Bills which the Australian Senate cannot amend. The Government is proposing that certain functions be passed from a Bill which we can amend and from a process which we have been able to amend to a process which we are no longer able to amend. We believe that to be a retrograde step and something that we will live to regret.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like the stamp allowance.

—It is interesting that Senator MacGibbon mentions the stamp allowance. I hope that is unfinished business. Our concern is to try to ensure that the Parliament does not lose its capacity to oversight these appropriations. The Minister has made it clear that we can examine them. I ask the Minister: When did we last amend Appropriation Bill (No. 1)? When did we last move a request that was acceded to? I cannot recall it; I doubt that my colleagues can recall it.
—You are the father of the House. You would know.
—Not quite. In fact, it has almost never been done. We used a process with some notoriety in 1975 but it took cognisance of the fact that we could not amend particular Bills.
—That is what we will have to do now; we are going to have to block Supply.
—Senator Boswell says that, in the event that there is an unsatisfactory feature, we may have to block Supply. I foreshadow that when we come to amendment 17, which is the next one, we will argue--
—And amendment 16.

—Amendments 14, 15 and 16 are being considered now. When we get to amendment 17 we shall be looking specifically at this question of the arrangements with the States and at some of the failures of process for which the Government stands condemned. It is not enough that the outcome is such and such if the process which got us there is quite unsatisfactory. We still assert that our proposed amendments 14, 15 and 16 are necessary and would be beneficial. We invite the Committee to agree to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who will be back in the chamber in just a moment. In the meantime I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Page 85, clause 221, lines 33 to 35, leave out the clause.

Those honourable senators who are following the debate may wish to turn to page 84 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. This draws attention once again to the enormity of this legislative package. Not only do we have three Bills but in this particular Bill we are going to 89 pages of legislation. I refer honourable senators to clause 221. It is the Opposition's view that this clause should be omitted. Clause 221 as it is proposed will repeal various sections of the Aboriginal Affairs (Arrangements with the States) Act 1973. Honourable senators may realise that this is the legislation under which arrangements were negotiated between the Commonwealth and the States in relation to Aboriginal affairs, arrangements which have been the basis for many of the agreements which have now lasted for some years and which underlie the sharing of services, the funding of services and the sharing of responsibilities. It is proposed in the clause that these parts of the Aboriginal Affairs (Arrangements with the States) Act 1973 be repealed and this is done as part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) package. It is really part of the group of amendments which we have been discussing for the last hour or two.

The Opposition wishes to oppose this proposal. Under the sections of the Act which this clause would repeal, the Governor-General and the Governors of the States may enter into arrangements relating to their respective responsibilities for Aboriginal affairs administration. Such arrangements have been made between the Commonwealth and all States, except the State of Queensland. That is another story. We deal directly with Queensland but not with the benefit of an arrangement made under this particular Act. I ask the Committee to consider that not only has the Commonwealth decided to repeal sections of this Act which identify the respective responsibilities of the Commonwealth and States for Aboriginal affairs legislation but that it was done without any consultation of any kind with the States. This proposal appeared in the ATSIC Bill of last year and the first the States knew about it was when the Bill appeared in Parliament.

This is at the very least evidence of clumsiness. It is probably evidence of quite gross discourtesy by the Commonwealth towards the State governments that, having entered into agreements in good faith and having operated those agreements, some of them for many years-I remind honourable senators that the Act to which it refers was an Act from 1973-it will repeal that Act and will bring this provision into this Parliament without having consulted with the States which are to be affected. Without any consultation with the States, clause 10, and presumably clause 18 which we have just discussed, were all inserted in the ATSIC Bill.

Presumably the effect of this clause is that the Commonwealth wishes unilaterally to abjure the arrangements. On its own that is a very significant act of government. At the very least the Commonwealth would have consulted with State Premiers; the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would have consulted with State Premiers to say that he would abjure certain arrangements which have been in existence for years. It was not done. Presumably the result of the passage of this clause will be that the States will henceforth have to negotiate with the ATSIC commissioners to obtain money for the States in ways which we have set out in the debate which has now gone on for some time.

I think it is important for the Committee to dwell for a moment upon the discourtesy and the clumsiness which this history of events, this record of events, sets out. We invite the Minister to tell us why this was done unilaterally. Why is it that the States first knew of this when the first Bill appeared in the Parliament in 1988? Was there some benefit from ambush? Is there some strategic necessity that the States not be advised in advance of a matter as significant as this? We have been concerned about some of the other clauses, but this seeks unilaterally--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens to all of the arrangements which they have already entered into with the Commonwealth? What is to happen to them?

—Senator Stone makes a very good point. Were I a State Premier, I would ask how I could have confidence in any arrangement which I had made with the Commonwealth on any matter, particularly if that arrangement required me to make some long term commitments or engage in long term planning. I simply would say, `Once burned--
—It is a total breach of faith.

—It is a total breach of faith, as Senator Stone says. We have a major concern about the process which was followed as it is revealed and set out in this particular clause of the ATSIC legislation. However, as a matter of law the arrangements which have been made continue in force. There are still arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States. Those arrangements do not disappear. The Minister has never referred to this. Perhaps the Minister has not actually considered what will happen to the arrangements presently in existence if the enabling Act is repealed.

—But presumably, those arrangements-and I have not looked at one for a long time-have clauses which actually provide for consultation between the Premiers or the relevant Ministers of the States and the respective Commonwealth Minister.

—Senator Stone may be right. I think it is proper that we should ask the Minister whether the arrangements provide, inter alia, for consultative mechanisms and, if so, what those consultative mechanisms are.
—And whether they are still extant.

—Whether they are still extant, and whether they were followed. I suspect that the answers will be that there are consultative mechanisms but that they were not followed and the States were not involved in any consultation-that the consequences are quite disastrous but the arrangements themselves may well continue. If that is the case, perhaps the Minister can tell us whether the arrangements will continue or cease to operate and, if so, from what date. Perhaps he can tell us the consequences of this particular clause being agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister actually told State Ministers at the AAAC meeting, the ministerial council meeting, on 18 November last year, that there was no intention-these were the Minister's words-to vary States grants. However, if this clause is retained and various sections of the Aboriginal Affairs (Arrangements with the States) Act 1973 are repealed, and if clause 10 stands-and we have already voted on that-and clause 18 stands, the matter will pass out of the Minister's hands. It will not matter what the Minister thinks because ATSIC will then have the powers conferred on it by the statute. Fine intentions butter no parsnips, as people say. The Minister may say that there is no intention to vary the arrangements, but if this clause is agreed to and clause 10 stands--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fine words, Senator.

—Fine words, are they? I thank Senator Stone-the matter will pass out of the Minister's hands. The Minister cannot tell this Committee what the intentions of the commissioners may be. Further-and this is a very important point-a document was sent to the States on 5 January 1989. That document purports to offer certain reassurances to the States. Let us listen to what the document says. It has quite a few numbered paragraphs. Paragraph 21 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth/State Arrangements. The ATSIC Bill repeals the States Grants (Aboriginal Assistance) Act 1976, and the substantive provisions of the Aboriginal Affairs (Arrangements with the States) Act 1973.
I interpolate that any concerns we have with the States Grants (Aboriginal Assistance) Act we will deal with at a later time. I return to the document:
This has led to a concern that States and the Northern Territory will somehow be disadvantaged.
Paragraph 22 states:
These concerns are again without foundation. The substantive provisions of the legislation to be repealed are incorporated in clauses 10 and 17 of the ATSIC Bill--
The reference to clause 17 should probably read `clause 18', but it depends which version of the Bill one has. I have confirmation that it is in fact clause 18. The document continues:

and specifically provide for the negotiation of `arrangements' between the Commonwealth and the States, and for States Grants programs. The current `arrangements' established under the 1973 Act are moribund, and in need of overhaul.
That is the view of the Commonwealth. Paragraph 23 states:
The Northern Territory Government, through its Chief Minister has expressed concern . . .
This concern is quoted in the following terms:

at the potential of provisions of the ATSIC Bill to alter the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory with respect to services for Aboriginal Territorians . . . In my view-
that is, the Chief Minister's view-
the crucial question of what financial powers and functions ATSIC will have has not been answered in the proposed legislation . . . '

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this suggesting that the Premier of Western Australia is trying to negotiate with the Commission to restore these arrangements?

—We have been arguing this point for some hours: the ATSIC Bill proposes in some of the clauses we have been looking at that the power to make section 96 grants, or their equivalent, should pass from the Commonwealth to the Commission.
—That is unbelievable.

—It is unbelievable, and we have been putting the view that it is certainly inappropriate and undesirable. The Northern Territory made a submission to the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs on which several of us served, three of us being in the chamber at present. In that submission it states that ATSIC:

SPEECH.PARA: has the potential to direct and channel funds currently made available by the Commonwealth to the States and Northern Territory earmarking them for specific purposes and also to determine distribution amongst States and Territories.
I note that my time is almost up. I wish to raise some more points relating to this most important clause, and I would welcome the chance so to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -I do not want to open the debate on local government and State rights again because it evoked some pretty strong feelings in the chamber between Senator Coulter and Senator Crichton-Browne. Whilst I would have to come down on the side of Senator Crichton-Browne, I do not think that we will gain anything by entering into that type of debate tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter does not support State rights. He has to realise that, whether he supports State governments or his Party's philosophy not to support State governments, it is a fact of life that State governments are here. Senator Stone entered the chamber and was shocked to realise--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did realise that this Bill was a bad Bill; but I did not realise that it was as bad as this.

—I will fill the honourable senator in. Under the ATSIC legislation as it stands a State Minister will have to go with cap in hand to a clerk, a commissioner or some employee of ATSIC. The approach will not be made on a direct Minister to Minister basis. We have been arguing about that for the last two or three hours. Unfortunately, we have not been able to get Senator Coulter to support our proposals. The situation gets worse with this particular clause. We are told that the State governments were not told about this provision before the legislation came out. In fact, the Minister told the State Ministers at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting on 18 November that there was no intention to vary State grants. If this clause is retained in the legislation the matter goes completely out of the Minister's hands. Not even the Federal Minister will have the right to grant allocations to the States. All allocations will be made through ATSIC. We can expect trade-offs-`We'll give you this if you do that', and `We want you to spend your money, not our money'. If ATSIC said, `We want you to do this and we'll provide the funds for it', that would be fair enough, but that will not happen. What will be said is, `We'll give you so much money if you will go ahead with a particular project'. There will be trade-offs and they will not be in the best interests of the Aboriginal people. Senator Stone expresses shock and horror.
—I do.

—I have been telling people ad nauseam for the past year this Bill goes beyond the bounds of anything that I have ever seen in this Parliament. Senator Tate says that it is not establishing a black parliament. It is a black parliament, all right. It is not only a black parliament that is being set up; it will be a parliament that will put itself above a democratically elected State Government. Even worse, if this clause is allowed to stay, it will put itself beyond this Federal Parliament, beyond this Senate. Under this clause ATSIC will make the allocations, not the Federal Government and not the State governments. That is usurping the power of a democratically elected government and a democratically elected Senate. The House of review will have no input. It can do nothing other than sit back and watch some kind of quasi, black parliament. I make no excuse for saying that. However I do not want to be racist. In fact, I have been trying to avoid that connotation throughout this debate. But that is what we are setting up. Let there be no mistake about that. It will be an Aboriginal parliament that will be able to bypass this Federal, democratically elected parliament. If a law dean of a university from Tasmania can support that he really ought to be ashamed of himself.

—I might be able to help the Committee. There has been some misunderstanding about the nature of the Aboriginal Affairs (Arrangements with the States) Act 1973. It deals with that time in the history of the rearrangement of responsibilities within the Federation for the welfare of Aboriginal people. It provides for the assumption by the Commonwealth of responsibilities and for the employment of persons who were engaged by State governments in the provision of such services. It is to those arrangements that section 5 of that Act refers. I am advised that it does not refer to the making of financial grants of assistance to the States. As I said earlier, it is to do with the consequence of the referendum which it was thought might require the Commonwealth assuming some of the departmental functions around the Federation. Having said all that, I do not believe that this clause in the Bill is necessary. Amendments No. 18 and No. 19 are amendments to clause 12 on page 9. Amendments No. 20 and No. 21 are amendments to the same clause on the following page. Clause 9 relates to ministerial directions. Our amendments are concerned with the power given to the Minister to issue directions. The first of our amendments requires some explanation. I can see the departmental officers smiling and I understand why. They would say, `You have been insistent upon a limitation of the power to issue directions being general directions when it was the case of the Aboriginal Development Commission', and so we did. But we are saying when it comes to ATSIC that that is not any longer an appropriate limitation. I do not want to argue that point but it really is the point of the argument. ATSIC is a differently constructed creature. It is a Commission with different powers. ATSIC is intended to cover the whole field of Aboriginal administration. We have only to go to the Minister's second reading speech, to the speeches of honourable senators who have taken part in an earlier debate on the second reading and to look at the speeches at the second reading stage here to understand that it is envisaged that ATSIC will have a very extensive role across the whole range of Aboriginal administration in this country. The purpose of ATSIC is to bring together under one heading services which were not previously operating together.
