TALK.START.PARA: —Before the sitting was suspended for dinner I had offered some argument in support of the amendments. Specifically, I had made the point-and I will not rehearse the whole argument again-that the giving of directions, other than general directions, is appropriate because of the very broad ambit and the very great reach of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). If there is to be an acceptable degree of ministerial control of ATSIC, and if there is to be an acceptable degree of accountability for the actions undertaken by ATSIC, the Minister really needs to have a power to direct the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: How much ministerial control is appropriate? The Opposition believes, as it does with the Aboriginal Development Commission, that no Minister should be able to direct the Commission as to the content of any advice that the commissioners may wish to give to him. We believe that any proposal for directions must provide adequate protection for sacred, secret information. I do not have to go over that argument; it is one which we raised when we were debating the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies Bill. I think we even raised it when we were discussing this legislation on Friday.

We therefore moved, as our first amendment in this group, that the word `general' be left out for reasons which I have stated. We have argued for the second of these amendments-that is, the amendment to clause 12 (2), lines 38 and 39-that we leave out `by the Commission to a Minister, Department of State or authority of the Commonwealth', and just say `to the Minister'. We believe it is appropriate that ministerial directions should relate to the content of advice, information or recommendations that may be given back to the Minister. We are not saying that advice should not be given to other bodies. But, as this is written, a ministerial direction may say that the Minister could otherwise direct the Commission to give advice to the Australia Council in relation to the Aboriginal Arts Board, or that it could authorise the Minister to give advice to that department of state-I think it is the Department of Administrative Services-which has the carriage of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and so on. That is why we have moved that amendment.
The other two amendments relate to clause 12 on page 10 of the Bill. Clause 12 (3) states:

Subsection (1) does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice, information or recommendation that may be given by the Commission to a Minister, Department of State or authority of a State or Territory, except for the purpose of protecting the confidentiality of information given to the Commission by the Commonwealth . . .
We do not understand why that subclause is necessary; we do not know why it is needed and we believe that it should be deleted.

In relation to clause 12 (5), we have suggested that the wording is not appropriate. Without going over the arguments again, I refer honourable senators to the debates we have already had where we have sought to deal with this question of culturally sensitive or secret and sacred information. We have been trying to get a form of words which would be acceptable to the Committee. I believe that we were able to reach an accommodation in some of the other areas and we are trying to do it again. We think the words that have been included in the Bill would be improved by deleting subclause (5) and substituting the subclause which we have proposed. Subclause (5) would then read:

A copy of a direction laid before the Parliament in accordance with subsection (4) shall not disclose any matters the disclosure of which in that manner would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.
We believe that that is an appropriate move.

In relation to subclauses (3) and (5) of clause 12 on page 10 of the Bill, I draw the Minister's attention to a report by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which, in 1989, made the following observations:
Clause 12 relates to the Commission performing its functions and exercising its powers in accordance with general directions given by the Minister.

Subclause 12 (3) states that the Minister is not empowered to give directions relating to the content of advice that may be given by the Commission to a Minister, Department of State or authority of a State or Territory
`except for the purposes of protecting the confidentiality of information . . .

Subclause 12 (5) states that a direction laid before Parliament by the Minister `shall not disclose any matters known to the Minister to be held sacred by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders . . .
The Scrutiny of Bills Committee then commented in the following terms:

The Committee fully appreciates the concerns of the Minister in this area, but in order to keep Parliament as fully informed as is reasonable in all the circumstances, felt that the Minister shall include a brief statement as to the general nature of any direction relating to sacred matters.
The Scrutiny of Bills Committee reported that the Minister responded. Leaving out the introductory paragraph, the Minister said:

This is an entirely legitimate concern, but is based on a misinterpretation of the clause in question. Subclause 12 (5) does not provide an exemption from disclosure where directions relate to sacred matters (a highly unlikely event), but rather provides that the mandatory publication of all directions (whether they relate to sacred matters or not) shall not disclose information of a sacred nature.
Consequently, the Parliament will always be informed, at least in general terms, of any directions made by the Minister.

The Opposition has looked at the subclause. I note that subclause (5) has what I consider to be a fatal weakness. I draw this particularly to the attention of Senator Coulter. If honourable senators look at the second line in subclause (5) they will see that it refers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Known to the Minister.

—Senator Coulter has anticipated me; it contains the words `known to the Minister'. I take it that the honourable senator realises the weakness of the words as written. This subclause would provide an absolute defence, should this ever be tested, for the Minister to say that such a matter was not `known to the Minister'. Why are the words there?

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, I do not want to become too difficult on this matter. We believe that there has been a common purpose in the Committee to look at these various provisions covering confidential or sensitive material in each of the Bills that have come before us. Amendment No. 21 has been moved in the same spirit and for the same reasons as we have put forward previously.

But, to be frank, I just cannot give such weight to the different scope of the functions and powers that might be exercised by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), as compared with the old Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), that would require such a degree of accountability to be taken by way of ministerial control and that would justify the giving of more specific directions than are envisaged by clause 12 (1), as drafted. SPEECH.PARA: All we are trying to do in clause 12 (3) is carry into effect the provisions in section 11 (2) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act, except that we have divided them into two proposed subsections-12 (2) and 12 (3). TALK.START.PARA: —Which sections of the ADC Act were those?
—Section 11 (2). Section 11 (1) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission-
that is, the ADC-
shall perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with such general directions as are given to it by the Minister in writing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dealing with suggested amendments Nos 18, 19, 20 and 21 by the Opposition, I agree with the Minister for Justice in relation to the first one. I have difficulty in seeing a difference between `general directions' and `directions'. When one puts in a term such as `general', which is of a non-specific nature, it is open to interpretation. I think that one could argue a great deal, and very unprofitably, about what is a general direction, a specific direction and a direction unspecified. So it seems to me that `general directions' is a slight but not a significant qualifier. There seems little point in leaving it out because I think that either wording would allow either situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some difficulty with the word `content' in clauses 12 (2) and 12 (3), because content could be the subject around which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was providing advice. In other words, the Minister might say, using the example we were using last night, `I'm going to give you directions in relation to building a sewer pipe on an Aboriginal settlement in Western Australia'. Strictly speaking, that is the content of the advice which the Commission will be providing. If the word `content' stands in the Bill, it seems to me that the use of that word, strictly interpreted, would prevent the Minister from giving any directions, because he could not give directions on the very thing about which he was seeking some sort of advice or information. I would like the Minister's comment on that. I would prefer the far more general words `relating to the nature of any advice'. The word `content', to me, has a more specific meaning, and I do not think that is what is intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the word `detail' is what you wanted-going to the detail of any advice. That narrows it, you see.

—It is a difficult area. I think I can see what it is that the Government is attempting to achieve. If he does not like the advice, he will send it back until he gets the advice he wants. But I do not think the word `content' actually achieves that.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning particularly to the words which the Opposition's amendment seeks to delete, I have some difficulty with this because when they are deleted the proposed subsection reads:
Subsection (1) does not empower the Minister to give directions relating to the content of any advice, information or recommendation that may be given to the Minister . . .

The Minister intended there is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. But it leaves entirely open the possibility that the Minister could give directions relating to content, in the sense in which I think it is meant, in relation to advice which the Commission might give to some other Minister, department of state or authority of the Commonwealth. I do not think that is what the Opposition is seeking to achieve. So I would have some difficulty with that. The word `content' in subclause (3) again causes me to hiccup a little. I wonder whether some other word might be more appropriate.

Dealing with the final amendment to subclause (5), I must say that I like the intent of the Opposition's amendment, because in general ignorance of the law is not a defence. It might be an excuse, but it is not a defence. The inclusion of the words `known to the Minister' provide, as Senator Peter Baume said, a complete let-out that should not really be there. The onus should be on the Minister if there is a breach of sensitivity, using Senator Baume's words. If there is a breach of sensitivity, the Minister should establish why it occurred. He should not simply be able to say, `Well, I did not know'. So I would support the intention of that amendment. If the Minister seeks to use different words more in line with words which have been used elsewhere, that would be quite acceptable to the Australian Democrats.

I have moved this large number of amendments together because, again, it would be foolish to do otherwise. They all deal with the question of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), which is the subject of division 6 of the Bill. The amendments relate to pages 23, 24 and 25 of the Bill, beginning at clause 44. The Opposition remains concerned about the unique arrangement whereby the Chief Executive Officer, as proposed, is to be something like a permanent head-as we understand that term-but is to appear to be a servant of and responsible to elected commissioners. It is quite interesting to look at the series of Bills which have preceded the one before us. Clause 37 (1) of the 1988 Bill read:
There shall be a Chief Executive Officer of the Commission who shall be appointed by the Minister.
Clause 44 of the 1989 Bill reads:
There shall be a Chief Executive Officer of the Commission.

I interpolate that we have yet to deal with one government amendment. This is the point at which it would appear that the Government now proposes to put back the words `who shall be appointed by the Minister'. I draw it to the attention of honourable senators that the Government had taken out the words `appointed by the Minister' and now wants to put them back in. No-one has explained why. The 1989 Bill already has a new subclause 44 (2) which actually says that the Minister is to appoint the CEO. It says:
The Minister shall consult the Commission before appointing a Chief Executive Officer other than the first Chief Executive Officer.

I understand the special problem that is related to the first Chief Executive Officer. Further, we know that when this Bill was in the House of Representatives the Government amended clause 44 yet again. It added clause 44 (5). This clause requires the Chief Executive Officer, `when requested by the Minister, to provide information or advice to the Minister on any matter specified by the Minister'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is who he is responsible to. When the Minister says `Jump', he will say `How high?'.

—Not only that but if the Minister says, `Tell me who said what and who voted which way' he will tell them. I did not need to mention this the other night, but if the Minister at any time requests information from the Commission itself the Chief Executive Officer will carry the delegation from the Commission on a day to day basis. That has been the case with other commissions and we expect that it would be the case now. The chief executive officer would normally do that job. But subclause (5), which has been added, could be called the `pimp clause', because it would require the Chief Executive Officer to answer questions on anything. I say to Senator Coulter that we are back to the question, which we have covered several times, of the phrase `on any matter specified by the Minister'. It is very interesting that it came in only when the Bill returned to the House of Representatives. If we look at clause 44 (5) we find that the Chief Executive Officer shall do this:

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of any policy determined or direction given by the Commission for the purposes of subsection (4).

We have thrown into relief the question we wish to put before the Committee. The question is: Whose executive officer will this person be? Will this person be the Chief Executive Officer of the Commission or a servant of the Minister? The more carefully one reads the clause and some of the subsequent matters the more concerned one becomes.

Statutory authorities of the Commonwealth practically always have the right to appoint their own chief executive. We are not saying this is always the case. I remind the Committee that when Mr John Menadue recently departed from Qantas Airways Ltd it was not the Minister who took that action. It was the board of Qantas which took that action, however wise or otherwise it might have been. Mr Menadue, as Chief Executive, was a servant of the Qantas Board. He was hired and fired by Qantas. That is the normal way in which chief executive officers relate to the boards of statutory authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for the Governor of the Reserve Bank.

—I did not say `always', and I am aware of some of the exceptions. Some of them are what might be called political appointments. Perhaps the Government has that in mind here, but that sits very poorly with any claim for self-management. I separate for one moment the question of the first Chairman, because I understand that there is a special situation that may apply during a transitional period. For example, to put it very simply, if no executive officer can be appointed at all except by the Commission, the Commission itself would have to start without a chief executive officer. The Minister, who may say he wants a transitional arrangement, may have a reasonable case for the appointment of a first Chief Executive Officer, provided it is understood that he would proceed from there to a proper appointment within a given time.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we are with this proposed clause and the Opposition has to decide what should be done. Subclause 44 (4) makes it clear that although the chief executive officer shall be appointed by the Minister-if the Government has its way-he is under the direction of the commissioners. He is appointed, hired and fired by the Minister, but answerable to the commissioners. This point is of immense importance when the question that must be answered is: Who advises the Minister and who administers legislation of the portfolio?

The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs actually looked at this matter. I refer honourable senators to paragraphs 2.9 to 2.22 where the question of ministerial advice came up and the rather awkward situation was canvassed by the Senate Select Committee. We think that the Government proposed subclause 44 (5) possibly as its response to the Senate Select Committee. One may say that subclause 44 (5) actually acknowledges that some of the concerns raised by the Senate Select Committee are valid. But the solution that has been proposed with subclause 44 (5) is quite bizarre. The Chief Executive Officer will be a creature with two heads and will have legally imposed duties which could actually be in conflict.

If the Minister asks for information, as the clause is drafted the CEO is required to give that information. For example, the CEO may be asked how the ATSIC board voted on this or that issue or which commissioners voted. According to the clause, he has no recourse but to answer those questions. He may have to answer a question such as what policy he intends to recommend to the board on a certain matter, and so on. The CEO will be obliged to reply, as will other officers of ATSIC who are answerable to the Chief Executive Officer.

If the Minister does not ask for information but asks for advice from the Commission, the same situation applies. The Minister has a choice of being advised by either the Commission or the CEO and his officers. If we are serious about Aboriginal self-management, we should not have this alternative route by which the Minister can go behind the commissioners to get information and advice from the Chief Executive Officer. The CEO's advice could be the same as the commissioners' advice. It may not be. If it is the same, the new provision is nugatory. He might give advice which conflicts with that of the commissioners or he might even give advice on a matter which is yet to be considered by the commissioners. It really is quite confusing. One could quite easily imagine a compliant, complacent CEO who owes his position to the Minister telling the Minister just what the Minister wants to know when what the Minister really requires is information from the Commission which tells it as it is.

At the very least the operation of new subclause (5) should be modified by a new subclause (6) requiring that the Minister should not be able to specify the content of any advice. I go back to what we have done before when we have had the same thing. The Minister can ask for general advice, but not for the content of specific advice because the difficulties are so great. We think it would be best if new subclause (5) which the Minister put into the Bill in the House of Representatives were defeated. It was an attempt to square the circle. If that is not possible, subclause (6) gives some little hope that the CEO could operate with a certain measure of integrity.

I now come back to the basic question. We do not think the Minister should appoint the Chief Executive Officer in any event. This brings us into conflict with the Government. I know we are not considering Government amendment No. 4, but it might be an appropriate time for me to raise the matter. If it were agreed to-and it is the one Government amendment we have not voted on-it would make it quite clear that the Minister would appoint the Chief Executive Officer. Surely, if we are on about Aboriginal self-management-we have been told that is so-the new Commission, in which we are investing so much, should have the capacity to appoint its own CEO. Again, I accept the fact that the Minister may have a special situation for the appointment of the first Chief Executive Officer.

Although we have several amendments, I will run through them. We want to change subclause (2) so that instead of saying, `The Minister shall consult the Commission before appointing a Chief Executive Officer'-that is, before the Minister appoints him-it will say, `The Commission shall consult the Minister before the Commission appoints a Chief Executive Officer'. We want to give expression to our view that it is properly a Commission appointment. That is the effect of our amendment (22). It is not inconsistent with the view we have been putting throughout that, if we are serious about a self-management Commission, allowing it to appoint its own Chief Executive Officer is not inappropriate. Because of that, a number of other amendments become necessary.

Amendment (23) is a proposed amendment to clause 47. It is really a consequential amendment because it then says that the Commission should grant leave of absence to the Chief Executive Officer, not the Minister. Why the Commission? If our first amendment is carried, the Commission will appoint the Chief Executive Officer, so the Commission should grant him leave of absence on such terms and conditions-that is our next amendment-as the Commission determines. (Extension of time granted) I do not want to take too much longer, but I will just keep the flow running. Amendment (24), again for the same reason, is an amendment to clause 49 seeking to leave out the word `Minister' and insert `Commission Chairperson'. For exactly the same reason, the reason I have argued, it does not require further argument from me, but it is part of the same question: Whose creature is the executive chairperson?

Likewise, amendment (25) proposes leaving out `Minister' and inserting `Commission Chairperson' in clause 50. It is precisely the same problem. Amendment (26) proposes leaving out `Minister' and inserting `Commission' in clause 47. Amendments (27) and (28) cover the same thing in relation to clauses 48 and 51. Clause 51 deals with the question of termination. Whereas the Government has proposed that the Minister may terminate the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer, our amendment, quite consistently with our other amendments, would reverse the situation and say `The Commission may, after consulting the Minister'. After all, if the Commission is to have the right to hire, it should have the right to fire as well. Amendment (29) is to exactly the same purpose. We want to put the power in the hands of the Commission, not the Minister. We are doing all this in the name of Aboriginal self-management. The same arguments apply to amendments (30) and (31).

I thank the Senate for letting me complete that explanation. I commend these amendments. They are consistent with Aboriginal self-management. We cannot understand why the Government thinks it necessary-apart from any recommendation it might make for the transitional period-to appoint the Chief Executive Officer of a Commission which it claims will be one to give expression to Aboriginal self-management. It makes a mockery of it if the Government then takes from that Commission the capacity to employ its own senior executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -Opposition amendments (22) to (31) moved by my colleague Senator Peter Baume should not give Senator Coulter any reason not to support them. Senator Coulter has been consistent in wanting to see the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) under self-management. There is no way in the world that a commission such as this could claim to have self-determination or self-management if the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs appoints the executive officer. For all sorts of reasons enunciated by Senator Baume, it just will not work. If the Commission is to work and to truly represent self-management and self-determination, it has to have the capacity to appoint its executive officer. If it cannot do that successfully, the whole ATSIC proposal falls to the ground. I could wax lyrical on all the things that could or could not happen. If the Minister has the right to hire and fire the executive, that person becomes a servant of the Minister; and I do not think we need that. I am sure we do not need that.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of us on this side of the Parliament have misgivings about the whole concept of ATSIC. I think the Australian Democrats and the National and Liberal parties are determined that if ATSIC has any chance of working-and, quite frankly, I do not think it will work in an iron lung-we have got to give it a go; and the only way we can do that is to let the Commission have the right to determine whom it hires and fires and who its executive officer will be. I say to Senator Coulter, the Democrats spokesman, that if this amendment is not carried the confidence that he is putting in ATSIC will be misplaced and ATSIC just will not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I indicate the Government's thinking at this stage it might help Senator Coulter in his response to our point of view and that of the Opposition. The Government can see the sorts of arguments that are being put in trying to deal with the fact that the Chief Executive Officer of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) will be in a peculiar and interesting position, but it is a position which, when one looks at subclause 44 (5), is an essential part of the Minister maintaining the flow of information such as enables him to discharge his responsibility to the Parliament. I know, for example, that during the various stages of Estimates committees and at Question Time in this chamber when honourable senators quite properly sought information as to matters which transpired at Aboriginal Development Commission meetings or relating to various decisions made by the Commission or its various staff or personnel in various parts of Australia, it was extremely difficult to obtain that information. I think some sort of provision to enable the information or advice to be obtained by the Minister so that he can properly discharge his responsibilities to the Parliament is a sound provision.

SPEECH.PARA: To go to the chief matter, the question of the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer: the chief executive officers of various enterprises and authorities of the Commonwealth may be appointed by boards, but generally where those enterprises are conducting a business operation of some sort or another. Like Senator Baume, I do not want to generalise across the whole range but generally one finds that the boards of government business enterprises appoint their chief executive officers, although I am advised that it is not particularly standard in other kinds of statutory authorities. The sorts of powers that will be vested in the Chief Executive Officer, the powers of the Secretary under the Public Service Act, include, for example, the ability to create, abolish and reclassify positions, transfer Senior Executive Service officers, recommend SES appointments and promotions, appoint non-SES officers under delegation from the Public Service Commissioner, promote and transfer non-SES officers, take disciplinary action, grant leave, retire non-SES officers, and give permission to undertake work outside the service. They are the sorts of matters which the Chief Executive Officer will have as part of his responsibilities, as would a secretary. In that situation it was thought appropriate that the Minister should appoint the Chief Executive Officer.

Circulated amendment (4) of the Government should have been in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill. It was left out by error. As Senator Baume quite properly points out, it is hinted at in clause 44 (2), which says:
The Minister shall consult the Commission before appointing a Chief Executive Officer . . .

That indicates that it was always intended that the Minister should appoint a Chief Executive Officer. Our circulated amendment to 44 (1) was intended to achieve that. As Senator Baume himself alluded to this matter, there may well be a need conceded by all sides for a Chief Executive Officer to be appointed prior to ATSIC really getting under way. In that situation the Minister has asked me to bring forward for the consideration of the Committee an amendment to clause 44 as follows:
Page 23, subclauses 44 (1) and (2), lines 21 to 23, leave out the subclauses, insert the following subclauses:
``(1) There shall be a Chief Executive Officer of the Commission who shall be appointed by the Minister.
``(2) The Minister shall not appoint a person as the Chief Executive Officer, except as the first Chief Executive Officer, unless the Commission agrees to the appointment.''.

The effect of this, when one combines it with clause 45 (2) (b) (i), which indicates that the first Chief Executive Officer can hold office for a term not exceeding two years, is that the first Chief Executive Officer to be appointed by the Minister during the preliminary period prior to ATSIC getting off the ground, would hold that appointment for a period of no more than two years. The Minister will have an untrammelled capacity to appoint the first Chief Executive Officer. From then on, the Chief Executive Officer could be appointed by the Minister only where he has the agreement of the Commission. In other words, there would have to be a mutually acceptable candidate for the position of Chief Executive Officer. The Minister has indicated that he would like the Committee to consider that particular proposal in the spirit of compromise. It takes up the point made by Senator Peter Baume as to the initial transitory period and, from then on, requires that the Chief Executive Officer be a mutually acceptable person-somebody to whom both the Minister and the Commission can agree. Mr Temporary Chairman, I am not sure how to proceed. There are amendments before the Chair from Senator Peter Baume. Shall I foreshadow moving these amendments? They come first in chronological order; that is the only thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to cooperate with the Minister, but it would help if we could have a couple more moments of discussion and then perhaps I can give an answer as to the way in which we might deal with this. I do not want to hold the matter up too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would seem to me that the middle course suggested by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) would overcome the problem raised by Senator Peter Baume. That is, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, after consultation with the Commission, where the Commission may provide advice unacceptable to the Minister, could still simply ignore that advice. The alternative situation is that the Commission, after consulting the Minister, may go ahead and ignore the Minister's advice. Would the Minister agree that a compromise might be that the Commission, with the agreement of the Minister, may grant leave of absence, and so on? If clause 44 (2), as amended by the Opposition, is acceptable perhaps clause 44 (5) can stay in. If the clause stands as printed, perhaps clause 44 (5) should come out. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter is quite right. We should look at clause 44 (5). I need a few moments to do that, and I will try to come back to his point. I recall that in an earlier clause which we considered, perhaps in one of the earlier Bills, we limited the capacity of a Minister to provide information or advice to any matter relevant to the functions of the body. Clause 44 (5) again refers to the provision of advice `on any matter'. That is the very minimum position. Of course, the Chief Executive Officer will have certain responsibilities in relation to staff, but I imagine Mr Menadue did as well. I invite honourable senators to look at those amendments.

I am seeking it because I see no good reason not to do it in this case, as I could see no good reason not to do it last week.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the proposal of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and of the Minister he represents. It is a not unreasonable proposal. TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I understand and share the concern expressed by Senator Peter Baume in relation to the powers of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I also understand the concerns expressed by the Government about accountability. The alternative method of dealing with this, as suggested by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), seems to me to be a reasonable compromise, namely that both parties-the Commission and the Minister-be locked together and mutually agree on the appointment of a Chief Executive Officer. If we pursue that course, would the Minister find a similar arrangement acceptable in relation to the other clauses which the Opposition is seeking to amend-in other words, that there be an agreement between the two parties regarding the various actions that are to be taken rather than simply a straight transfer of power? It seems to me that if one could accept that compromise all the way through, one would achieve the objective of accountability, which the Government is quite rightly seeking, and also the objective sought by the Opposition, which is that the Commission have real power in this area and be able to initiate the appointment, dismissal, leave of absence and various other matters covered in these clauses. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) responds, let us think about the question of termination. Let us assume that the Minister agrees to follow Senator Coulter's course. It may wish to terminate the employment of that officer and may not have the agreement of the Minister so to do. While I understand Senator Coulter's argument for the employment of a Chief Executive Officer, I do not agree with it. I think the decision that the Australian Democrats took on the Aboriginal Development Commission-that the Commission should appoint its own-was a more appropriate way to go. If employment can be terminated only by agreement between both parties and that agreement cannot be reached, ATSIC might be unable to sack its Chief Executive Officer if it thought that to be a necessary step.

SPEECH.PARA: I can go only on the experience available, but I am not happy with the way in which the Aboriginal Development Commission dealt with some of its senior officers last year. Nevertheless, if I believe in self-management, it is better that Aborigines have the capacity to deal with their own executives than have to get the agreement of the Minister so to do. We could end up in a situation that we had not intended. The same might apply to leave of absence. If we said that leave of absence had to be granted by agreement but that agreement could not be obtained, we could have a Commission unable to give leave of absence to its Chief Executive Officer. This is why the course the (Australian) Democrats took last week on the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill was a better course. It is more consistent with the concept of self-management. I still believe that it is the course to follow. I do not know how we will resolve the various difficulties if the Minister responds favourably to the Democrats' proposed subsequent amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the whole, I agree with Senator Coulter's line of thinking. For example, I think the best way to approach clause 47 would be to say that the Minister may, after consulting the Commission, grant leave of absence to the Chief Executive Officer. It would be quite ludicrous to have a need for agreement. Matters such as leave of absence, appointment of an acting Chief Executive Officer, as set out in clause 48, and other terms and conditions, as set out in clause 52, ought to be able to be dealt with by consultation.

I think the terminology used in clause 51 (1) should remain. Subclause (1) states:
The Minister may, after consulting the Commission, terminate the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer because of incompetence, misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.

I think those words can remain. In other words, agreement is required for the appointment of the Chief Executive Officer. From then on, the Minister needs to consult the Commission at every stage in relation to other matters set out in division 6 in relation to the Chief Executive Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, certain matters attract my attention straight away. An obligation to consult does not mean very much. A Minister could consult the Commission and then ignore it. In fact, I have seen many times this requirement to consult. It does not mean that there is a requirement to get agreement. It simply will not do. Consultation does not of itself solve the problem. It does not really add anything to the formula that is already in existence. It certainly does not overcome the problem which I have outlined. If there is agreement between the Commission and the Minister, there is no problem. The problem arises where they are in disagreement. I predict now to the Committee that there will be many occasions when a Minister and the Commission will be in disagreement. I imagine there could be such occasions concerning the Chief Executive Officer. There was a crisis relating to a chief executive officer last year in the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). It will not be the last. This kind of thing will recur.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not trying at this stage to prevent a proper course of action. I cannot understand why the Minister wishes to reserve to himself the right to hire and to fire the Chief Executive Officer. I have heard no compelling argument for it. This proposition sits as badly with the concept of Aboriginal self-management here and it is as unnecessary as it was with the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill. We would not wear it then. We described it in that Bill as an attempt to limit the powers of the ADC, which is what it was. I say to Senator Coulter that this is an attempt to limit the powers of the Commission in favour of the Minister of the day. I also say to the honourable senator as to his own formulation of what might be appropriate: the hiring matter is one thing but some of the subsequent matters need further attention. I put to him, from experience, that a suggested amendment to consult will not solve the problem. It is not adequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have had an interesting committee debate in relation to this Bill. Senator Peter Baume has put forward some interesting points arising out of his own experience. I would be willing to say to the Committee that if the Government's proposals-to insert new clause 44 (1) and new clause 44 (2) requiring that the Minister, except for the appointment of the first chief executive officer, appoint a person as chief executive officer only with the agreement of the Commission-are agreed to by the Committee, all the other matters in division 6 which confer on the Minister some sort of power in relation to the chief executive officer, whether it be as to leave of absence, the appointment of an acting chief executive officer, the termination of appointments or other terms and conditions, should be done only with the agreement of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, to be consistent in division 6 the new clauses 44 (1) and 44 (2) will include that the Minister shall make appointments, grant leave of absence, appoint an acting chief executive officer, terminate an appointment and determine the terms and conditions only with the agreement of the Commission. It will take some time to get the consequential amendments written up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just ask the Minister: what are the compelling reasons for the Government taking the threshold step and wishing to say, `We wish to appoint the chief executive officer'? I suspect that it is that the Government may not actually trust the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander commissioners always to make a choice of which the Government approves. I do not believe that there are special statutory duties that can only be fulfilled by a Government appointee. So before I respond to the Minister's suggestion, I would like to know on the threshold question why this must be a ministerial appointment.

—I have tried to explain that the Government believes that it is important that the Parliament have a Minister who is responsible to it, who can answer for the appointment of this chief executive officer and for the way in which the duties of the chief executive officer in an important body, such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, carries out his or her duties. The Government's desire to have that ministerial, as it is now, pre-eminence but within a mutually acceptable agreement with the Commission, is the appropriate way in which the matter should be structured. My advisers tell me that in relation to section 48 relating to the appointment of an acting chief executive officer it may be important when we have a deadlock and no agreement can be reached as to the appointment of the chief executive officer--
—As an acting chief executive officer.

—There could be an acting chief executive officer to appoint somebody after consultation rather than with agreement. In other words, there may be a situation where we could not leave the Commission without somebody fulfilling those duties over a period of time whilst an agreement was reached. That might take some time because of the need to carry out a full process which leads to a mutually acceptable person being appointed. As I am now advised, the better amendment to section 48 (1) would be that the Minister may, after consultation with the Commission, appoint a person to act as the chief executive officer. But with that variation and with what I have already indicated concerning other matters, a mutually agreed position will have to be reached as to appointment, termination of appointment, the granting of leave of absence and the terms and conditions under which the chief executive officer will hold office.

—Section 48 really does not help us very much. I cannot believe that the Minister says that the reason it is necessary is that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander commissioners may be unable to reach a decision. I could resolve that. I am reminded of the words of the Lord Chancellor in Iolanthe when to solve the problem that occurred at the end of that opera he said, `As an old legal draftsman, just add one word'. So we simply say, `The Commission shall appoint a person to act as his chief executive officer'; it simply imposes an obligation. Why do we keep coming up with hypothetical situations in which we are saying, `You must understand that the black commissioners may not be able to handle this'?
—We are not saying that at all.

—I am sorry. That is what it sounds like. Why would they not be able to? The board of Qantas Airways Ltd can appoint its own acting chief executive officer. I cannot understand any convincing argument which would make me believe that we should take away from the commissioners-they would expect to have this power-the power to appoint, to hire, to fire, to replace temporarily, to grant leave of absence to their own chief executive officer. I cannot understand at the threshold why we take that course. That is the reason I am asking about the threshold question before we try to deal with all of the details.

—I will answer Senator Peter Baume's question in the way in which I see the threshold matter. Senator Peter Baume has argued, as I have indicated to him already, extremely persuasively for his position. I think there is an enormous amount of merit in what he is saying. Throughout this debate people on his side of the Senate have argued that we must not create a black parliament. Those people have been arguing very strongly that ATSIC is not a parliament and that it does not have the same powers as the parliament does. There is another principle which needs to be observed here: that is the one of being responsible to this Parliament through the Minister. My threshold position is one of trying to balance on the one hand the very valid arguments that Senator Peter Baume is putting-that is, the same arguments that I have already put myself in relation to self-determination and self-management-with the other point which the Opposition has been so insistent upon throughout this debate: that ATSIC is not a parliament and it has to be answerable to this Parliament. It seems to me that the compromise that was suggested by the Minister-where the two sides agree on those things-is the appropriate balance and is the threshold, as far as I see it. It is a balancing act between two principles, both of which have been eloquently enunciated by the honourable senator's side in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: -I think that Senator Coulter said it all when he said that it was a compromise. He has used that word the last two or three times that he has risen to speak. Compromises are usually the worst solution; they are neither right nor wrong and they lead to the worst possible result. In other words, a bad decision is better than no decision. At the moment we are trying to compromise the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). We have probably debated only 10 per cent of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand Senator Coulter. When we debated the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill he agreed that the Commission should have the right to appoint its own executive officer. I suppose he is trying to compromise. I do not know why he does not stick to his guns and give ATSIC the same rights that he gave the Aboriginal Development Commission only a couple of days ago. In fact, if I can recall correctly, when this question was being debated Senator Coulter said, if I can quote him, that he hoped Senator Tate would observe his remarks about self-determination right through the ATSIC Bill. I say to Senator Coulter, with the best will in the world, that if he wants ATSIC to work-quite frankly, it is on his shoulders and he carries a very heavy responsibility on behalf of the Australian Democrats and 360,000 Aboriginals-the only way in which it will work, if it works at all, is by trusting the Aboriginal people. We all acknowledge that mistakes will be made, but it will only be by the mistakes that the Aboriginal people make that they will learn.

They will never learn at all if the Minister is in there protecting them, propping them up and supporting them, because the Aboriginal people will just fall back and say, `Oh well, the Minister is running this. He has his own boys in here. We will just turn up for the ride'. That is exactly what we do not want to happen. I have seen this happen many times in Aboriginal communities: Aboriginal people are going well, making their own decisions and then someone-generally it is the Queensland Government-pulls white advisers out. As soon as that happens, the Commonwealth puts another white adviser in to organise one of its programs. I have seen that happen so many times: Aboriginal people are sitting there doing the right thing and making their own decisions and all of a sudden someone comes in, and the Aboriginals lie back in the traces and say, `Oh well, he will do it'.

What the Nationals and the Liberals are saying is, `Let us give them a go. They may make mistakes, but by making mistakes they will get better'. SPEECH.PARA: Later we will be spending some time on the whole electoral process. I remind Senator Coulter of some of the concerns he expressed on more than one occasion during the sittings of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. We will have time to go over that later. It makes one wonder about the validity of the assumption that the elected regional councils, as they are planned to be elected, will truly, accurately and fairly reflect the wishes of the people who are represented by the elected councillors, but that is another question. The Government proposes this process and justifies it because it is thought to promote Aboriginal self-determination, as the Minister has said, or to quote clause 3 (a) of the Bill:
to ensure maximum participation of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of government policies that affect them;

We have already referred to the fact that that is government with a small `g', meaning more than one level of government; but that is an argument that we have already had. Certain councillors of the NAC were elected on quite factional votes-on votes related to kinship and often on votes not related to any involvement or demonstrated capacity. I am speaking from experience. I can identify people. I can think of representatives in certain States who were there because they came from large and extensive kindreds who could be got out on election day. Further, there were very small turnouts, and again that is a matter that will be referred to later.

But even if the elected councillors are representative-and I applaud the idea of a proportional representation system here-the councillors may well align themselves with factions within a regional council. The danger we face is that of the winner takes all. It may operate to the detriment of any minority within a regional council. I remind honourable senators of the experience we had on the mid-north coast of New South Wales where some Aboriginal associations of Kempsey were funded. It turned into a factional battle with winners and losers. Far from an attempt to deal with the whole community, we had the winning faction making sure that all the resources and money were confined to the members of that faction-whether it was housing, vehicles or anything else-and we had the losers responding with quite a dramatic show of force: axes were put through the sides of motor cars and quite violent means were employed. That Kempsey situation became quite electric, and that was because the money that was given out at that time was used in a way that provided spoils to the victors and vae victi-woe to the vanquished.

So there are many concerns about a distribution of resources and how decisions might be made within the regional councils. Again, that is something that the regional councils themselves will have to work through. The only warning I give to the Government, from experience, is that there will be great bitterness. While it will be directed to the regional councils, it will also be directed to the Government. If people now in receipt of assistance suddenly find that that is cut off for factional, family or regional reasons within a regional council area, there will be great bitterness. Anyone with any practical experience within the area of Aboriginal affairs could not argue that these things will not happen or have not happened. I have too much specific experience of these matters on which to draw.

There could be many reasons, then, why the noble ideals of the regional councils-the function of Aboriginal grassroots democracy-might work suboptimally or might not work very well at all. But in clause 63 the Government seems to put all its eggs in the self-determination basket. It is one thing for the Minister to be able to vary the proposed regional council budget, but if this clause becomes operative and the Minister has to put a statement before the House explaining why he has varied a regional budget, it may well expose him to ridicule, because some of the reasons will be quite difficult to explain. If I were doing it-and I put my mind back to the Kempsey situation-I would have to say, `I am varying the budget because the people up there are not playing fair. They are depriving 30 per cent of their community of access to any resources at all'. That is an actual example I can use from history, and not so long ago.

I am just wondering why the Minister should have to lay those kinds of details before the Parliament. It will probably make more difficulties for the Ministers than it will resolve. Looking at the noble ideals one might say that, if the Minister wishes to intervene, he has to explain his reasons. I just warn honourable senators that the reasons for which the Minister will intervene will be few and will relate in the end to the kinds of rather unhappy circumstances to which I have referred in my remarks. I suggest that this clause could well be left out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I found it a little difficult to follow Senator Baume's drawing on the memories that he has of the time when the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC) was in existence. I believe that then we had single member electorates with a first past the post system of voting, whereas with the regional councils at least we have a multi-person electorate with a Senate-type system of voting. Perhaps the principles of winner take all and woe to the vanquished will not be so easily brought about in that system of voting. I acknowledge that there are always dangers of some favouritism in the way in which a regional council might recommend that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) make moneys available to those organisations which might provide services to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Let us not forget that that is the function of a regional council.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple purpose of clause 63 is to put a constraint on the Minister so that he does not ignore the regional councils and simply override them without coming into the Parliament and saying why he is overriding them. There may be difficult situations such as those outlined by Senator Baume where it might be thought that a sensitivity of language is required in explaining to the Parliament why a view was taken as to the way in which funds might be distributed in a region other than in accordance with the recommendations of the relevant regional council. I am sure that Senator Baume would not find it difficult to find a form of words which conveyed the true reason-there is no need to hide the sorts of concerns he was expressing; I think they ought to have been expressed-if a similar situation were to arise in the future, and I believe it could be done in a way which allowed the Parliament to make a judgment as to whether the regional councils were being regarded with contempt or disdain or as of no consequence in the preparation of the Estimates. So I believe it is simply a question of controlling the Minister, of making sure that the Minister, in being accountable to Parliament, fully acknowledges and perhaps gives primacy to the recommendations of the regional councils and really has to explain why it is thought to be necessary to depart from those recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely delighted to hear the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) extol the virtues of the Senate proportional representation system and explain how representative it is. I cannot help but remember the arguments we had over the Australian Capital Territory electoral processes and the way in which the Australian Democrats' attempt to get that more representative system was not accepted by the Government. Beyond that, I accept the arguments that the Minister then went on to put. It seems to me that one of the aspects of accountability has to be openness. Indeed, if the circumstances that Senator Baume has outlined are to occur, it is appropriate, with or without nice words, that that be explained and made quite clear. It may well be, as the Minister says, that half the population in a particular regional council is holding the other half to ransom with lumps of four-by-two or something like that. It gives the other half an opportunity to say, `Well, that is not true; the Minister has been misled'. Unless there is some openness in the explanations as to why the Minister is varying the Budget, then those who feel either advantaged or abused by those decisions have no opportunity to intrude and cause them to be varied.

SPEECH.PARA: As I recall, this clause arose out of one of the concerns expressed by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The Committee was concerned that regional councils should be accountable in the drawing up of their budgets and subsequently in the discharge of those budgets. If the Minister chooses to vary those budgets he has to be accountable too. That again is giving effect to the principle of self-determination by those regional councils. The openness which this process involves is the most important principle here. It is the openness which allows both sides to see quite transparently what is being done, on the one hand, by the regional councils and, on the other hand, by the Minister to ensure that fairness and justice prevail.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee stood over eight amendments to clauses 47 to 52. There were two amendments to clause 47, one to clause 48, one to clause 49, one to clause 50, two to clause 51 and one to clause 52 which the Minister mentioned orally to the Committee but did not formally move.
