SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Page 6, paragraph 6 (2) (c), line 40, leave out ``may'', insert ``has the capacity to''.
(35) Page 8, after new subclause 7 (4), add the following new subclause:
``(5) Nothing in this section or in any other provision of this Act shall be read as conferring on the Commission a function of acquiring land except:
(a) for its administrative purposes; or
(b) for the purpose of the performance of functions expressly conferred on the Commission by this Act.''.

(36) Page 10, subclause 14 (1), line 24, after ``corporations'', insert ``for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations to occupy that land''.
(37) Page 11, paragraph 15 (b), lines 17 and 18, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph and words:
``(b) land and such personal property as the Commission considers appropriate;
for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations to occupy that land.''.

The purpose of this group of amendments relates to the acquisition of land by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). These clauses are so drawn that they would not prevent the acquisition of land for purposes which are proper purposes to be occupied or used by Aboriginal people. We believe that, as presently drafted, paragraph 6 (2) (c) simply says that the Commission may acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property. We believe that, if the Commission used that power in a certain way, it could become a de facto national Aboriginal land council. The Minister may well say that was never the intention. We simply look at the statute and ask: How could it be used by a commission that wished to acquire, hold and dispose of land that way? It could become a de facto Aboriginal land council nationally. It would be possible under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill for the Commission to devote funds provided to it for land acquisition and to use them for acquisition by the Commission itself on a large scale. I imagine that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) would tell us that that is not the intention. The fact remains that the legislation as it is written would enable ATSIC to act in the way described above.

If we combine that paragraph with the other wide powers proposed for ATSIC, the Commission could become a very influential agency in the general Australian economy. If we look at the Aboriginal Development Commission Act and get some guidance from that, we find that under section 27 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act the ADC can acquire interests in land and then vest those interests in Aboriginal corporations. I emphasise the words `and then vest those interests in Aboriginal corporations'. However, the ADC can do this-and I quote from the ADC legislation-only `for the object of enabling Aborigines to occupy land'. There is a separation in the ATSIC Bill of clauses 6 and 14, and there is the omission of the words `for the object of enabling Aborigines to occupy land' from clauses 14 and 15. Without those words, I think it would be possible for the Commission at large to become a very large autonomous land-holder for its own purposes.

It would be fair at some stage during this Committee consideration for the Committee to examine the extent to which it would wish to see the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as a large autonomous landholder in its own right. It is my belief that that is not an appropriate way to go. If we look at the amendments that have been moved here to clause 6 we see that ATSIC has the capacity to acquire, hold and dispose of land. In clause 7, where we add a new subclause (4), we then qualify the right to hold land in the following way:

Nothing in this section or in any other provision of the Act shall be read as conferring on the Commission a function of acquiring land except for its administrative purposes or for the purpose of the performance of functions expressly conferred on the Commission by this Act.

We are not seeking to prevent the Commission from acquiring land. I go back to the experience with the ADC. The ADC acquired Bonner House in Woden. It acquired it for two reasons. It was used for investment as part of the capital fund and it was used for the administrative purposes of the ADC. It is perfectly proper that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission should be able to acquire land for its own administrative purposes. We do not object to that at all. Neither would we object to it acquiring land for the performance of functions expressly conferred on the Commission by this Act. Simply to allow it to acquire land at large from its own very large budget may be quite inappropriate. It is fairly common knowledge that the interim commissioners are going to include certain people who have been very active in the national land rights movement and who are committed to this course of action. I will name them later if honourable senators want me to.

We believe that what we are concerned about is not fanciful; it comes from a reading of the clauses of the Bill. I put it to the Committee that these two amendments will not prevent ATSIC from acquiring or holding land but will limit the circumstances under which it shall do so. The other two amendments which have been moved together are amendments to clauses 14 and 15. Each of them relates to a capacity of ATSIC to hold grants of interest in property or to give grants for the acquisition of property. We have included them within the same groups of amendments because they relate to the same general matter.

I refer honourable senators to the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. This is a model that we can look to. In that legislation interest in land can be granted to an Aboriginal land trust-other than an Aboriginal land trust established under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act-or interest in land could be granted to an Aboriginal corporation. The words in section 23 of the ADC Act state:
. . . for the purpose of enabling Aborigines who are members of that corporation or land trust to occupy that land.

There have been several ATSIC Bills. Let us look at the 1988 ATSIC Bill. It omitted any reference to what might have been the purpose of the grant of interest in property or grants for the acquisition of property. It seemed to follow that a grant of an interest in property could be made to an Aboriginal corporation for any purpose. The Opposition seeks to move an amendment to clause 14 to insert the words `for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of those corporations to occupy that land'. All we are saying is that by all means there should be capacity to acquire grants of interest in property. But it should be for the purpose of enabling appropriate Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders to use that land. If it is not the intention of the Minister to promote a national system of land rights by the back door let us make that explicit.

I have illustrated already that the kind of words we are trying to add are words which are already contained in the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. They were put into that Act for very good reasons. They have not prevented the ADC from proceedings to acquire or hold land. Compared to the 1988 Bill the 1989 Bill which we are now considering inserts a new subclause 14 (4) which is a tightening up of the business enterprise grants conditions. It is drafted in such a way as to provide the capacity for ATSIC to make grants of interest in property for purposes other than business enterprises. When we read that subclause we are quite concerned about it. Under clause 88 of the ATSIC Bill, which again is related, an Aboriginal corporation is defined as any body corporate owned or controlled by Aboriginal people. If we come back to clause 14 with that definition in mind ATSIC could make grants of interest in property to any Aboriginal corporation for any purpose other than for a business enterprise because that is controlled by subclause 14 (4).

Let me tell the Committee what some of these bodies might be. Eligible corporations to hold land provided by ATSIC could include each of the regional councils to be set up under the Bill. They are going to be body corporates owned or controlled by Aboriginal people. It could include the Northern Territory land trusts or land councils. Honourable senators may wish to refer to paragraph 22 (1) (c) of the Northern Territory (Land Rights) Act. It could include the New South Wales land councils. It could include Aboriginal legal, medical or similar services if they are incorporated. This could happen the way the Bill is written. Any of them could hold land. It could include bodies such as the Aboriginal Coalition. It could include the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation if it was incorporated. It could hold large amounts of land. It could include an Aboriginal incorporated company-say, a shelf company. It could include an Aboriginal council or association which is formed under the Aboriginal Councils or Associations Act. As presented to us it is clear that ATSIC would be able to grant property interests to a very wide variety of Aboriginal organisations. All they have to do is be incorporated.

If it was the desire of the commissioners to pursue an agenda of extensive land acquisition other than the kind of land acquisition which we have indicated in our amendments it would be possible for the commissioners to do so under the Act as it is written and presented. A de facto national Aboriginal land rights scheme could thus be developed by recourse to this clause. I am setting this out for the future commissioners in case they had not realised that this capacity exists. We have not tried to prevent, with our amendments, the acquisition of land for the purpose of enabling Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders who are members of the corporations to occupy that land. We are not trying to stop that. We have tried to insert those words at least to put some limit on the capacity to acquire land which would seem reasonable and proper. The same thing was done in amendment No. 37 where we sought to define a purpose, enabling Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who are members of the corporations to occupy that land. I may have some more to say about the amendments but I introduce them with those comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. 36 moved by the Opposition is to clause 6 (2) (c). The Opposition seeks to remove the word `may' from the expression `may acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property' and replace it with the words `has the capacity to'. I have great difficulty in seeing the difference between those two. If the Commission has the capacity to do that, clearly it may do it.
—Under conditions which will be laid down later in the other amendments.
—Yes; but, as it stands, on its merits, I do not see that there is a difference. I pick up Senator Baume's interjection that taken together with his other amendments it perhaps becomes significant.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition amendment No. 35 taken by itself, again, does not mean a great deal. Of course, taken with amendments Nos. 36 and 37, the amendment takes on a particular meaning. Therefore, amendments Nos. 36 and 37 show the substantial difference between the intention of the Opposition and the intention as expressed by the Government in this legislation. Several times while Senator Baume was speaking, he used the terms, `occupy the land' and `use the land'. One of the things that I find quite objectionable about many people in Australian society is that if Aboriginal people do not `use' land in the same way as Europeans `use' land-which usually means exploiting the land in some way-they are regarded somehow as lesser individuals for that attitude to land.

The difference is something that we must recognise. Aboriginal people have a different relationship to land and they may simply want to hold land in the same way as European people may want to hold a sacred object, a church or something else, and not actually use it. It might have a heritage value or something like that. They would not use it in the sense of exploiting it. Therefore, I find the intention behind amendments Nos 36 and 37 rather objectionable because they suggest the imposition on Aboriginal people of a European-type attitude to land. Surely that is not what ATSIC is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't they occupy it?

—As it stands, they may not occupy it. They may regard a piece of land as a sacred area and simply want to ensure that it is preserved. They may not physically occupy it. Moreover, what is occupation? If there are two Aboriginal people on 100 square kilometres of territory, is that occupation or do 5,000 need to be on that land? What is occupation? I find the idea that Aboriginal people can acquire land only for purposes which fit within the prevailing European-type philosophy somewhat objectionable.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, this acquisition will go on within a budget-we have dealt already with some of the budget questions-which will be drawn up by regional councils and ATSIC itself. The draft budgets will be surveyed by the Minister. The Minister will have an oversight and the ability to vary those budgets. The reasons for varying the budgets will be able to be laid before both Houses of Parliament. There will be an open disclosure of the whole process. It seems to me extremely unlikely that, through this mechanism, Aboriginal people will acquire large blocks of land simply to be left lying idle.

I find it rather peculiar for the Opposition to complain if some blocks of land bought for speculative purposes are not actually occupied, because we cannot get the Opposition to agree to a register of foreign ownership in this country. The Opposition will not even agree to inquiring into foreign people coming in and speculating in Australian land, so I find it objectionable that the Opposition should complain if Aboriginal people were to buy some pieces of land, not occupy them and use them purely for speculative purposes. Why should they not do so? Why should they not take advantage of that system? But I do not see that as a very significant occurrence in view of the protections which are laid elsewhere in the Bill.

In summary, I cannot see the point of the amendment to clause 6 (2) (c). I have indicated that I oppose amendments Nos 36 and 37. As Senator Baume has said, those words take on some significance only if other amendments are accepted. I do not accept those other amendments. However, I do not find at all exceptional the proposed additional subclause to clause 7. It takes on a repugnance only if we proceed, as I indicated, with amendments Nos 36 and 37. Of course, if those amendments are not accepted, Senator Baume may not want to proceed even with the addition to clause 7. Under those circumstances, he may choose to withdraw that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Coulter suggesting that we should consider amendments Nos 36 and 37 first and then make a decision on whether to proceed with No. 35?

—Yes. I would think that would be the logical sequence because amendments Nos 36 and 37 make the substantial difference. I do not support them because I find them objectionable. If they are not accepted, as I have indicated, the first amendment, No. 32, has little meaning and No. 33 probably has little meaning also. I do not object to it, but because of the deletion of Nos 36 and 37, Senator Baume may choose not even to proceed with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the same difficulty as Senator Coulter as regards narrowing the range of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who might be aided by the ability in the Commission to purchase land to those who might occupy that land. I was not quite sure whether the word `occupy' was being used as an alternative to the word `residency' or whether there was some wider scope that could be envisaged by it. That needs to be explained by Senator Baume. Does it require some sort of demonstrated physical presence on the land, if not the building of a structure or some fixture over a period of time? If so, given the huge expanses that we are concerned about, or possibly concerned about, in what way would an occupation be demonstrated?

SPEECH.PARA: In any case, it may well be that there are occasions where, as Senator Coulter quite correctly pointed out, the reason for the purchase of the land might be to advance a social, cultural or spiritual interest of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people which precluded occupation by those persons of the particular stretch of land or property or area that was being purchased or considered for purchase. As I say, it might very well be the values which suggest that it would be a good thing to purchase the property which militate against anybody setting foot on that land. I believe it is too restrictive. For example, one might also want to hold the land for some land-based enterprise-perhaps some sort of food gathering or horticultural activity of a type which does not, in our terminology, amount to an occupation but which does, nevertheless, involve a certain use of the land as we would see it. It seems to me that this unnecessarily narrows the range of legitimate reasons which might commend themselves to the Commission and, therefore, I indicate that the Government cannot accept amendments 36 and 37.

I cannot see the point of amendment 34 to clause 6 as suggested by Senator Baume. I think `may acquire' means that the Commission has the capacity to acquire but it is not compulsory that it acquire. There are two senses of `may'. One is conferring a discretionary power rather than a mandatory requirement-`may' do something rather than `shall' do something. But in this instance it tends more to the meaning of having a capacity to do something. I think that the amendment is simply unnecessary. I agree with Senator Coulter that if amendments 36 and 37 are rejected by the Committee, amendment 35 could be accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in the debate last night, a number of issues go to the fundamental principles of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act. I draw to the attention of the Committee the importance of always being mindful of the preamble to the legislation which is listed at the front of the Bill. We are considering four proposed amendments by Senator Peter Baume. Amendment No. 34 relates to division 1, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission itself; amendment No. 35 specifically relates to the functions of the Commission; amendment No. 36 specifically relates to grants of interest in property; and amendment No. 37 specifically relates to grants for acquisition of property. These amendments seek to change very fundamental parts of the legislation. As Senator Peter Baume said in his initial comments, we have to be mindful of whether or not the legislation creates a vehicle for a national land rights network, particularly in the various States of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act makes specific provisions for land rights in the Northern Territory. Senator Peter Baume has already highlighted the area where this legislation could be read in conjunction with the grants to either a Northern Territory Aboriginal land trust or the land councils of the Northern Territory. The legislation would, therefore, have a very wide application with regard to other land that does not necessarily have to be subjected to the determinations and hearings of the land commissioners in terms of the special needs, identifications and traditional establishments that are so important under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory. But, of course, this digs deeper because it could well have that same application in every other State of the Commonwealth of Australia. The preamble to the Bill states very specifically:

. . . AND WHEREAS the people . . . known as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia were the prior occupiers and the original owners of this land . . . AND WHEREAS they were dispossessed . . . have no recognised rights over land yet recognised . . . AND WHEREAS . . . reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land . . . AND WHEREAS it is the firm objective of the people of Australia that policies and programs be maintained and developed by the Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, that will overcome the economic and social disadvantages of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples . . . AND WHEREAS it is appropriate to establish measures for the furtherance of the aforementioned objective . . .

The legislation, as it is drafted, provides the very mechanism whereby the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), could provide, as Senator Peter Baume has outlined in considerable detail, by making grants to the various bodies that can be incorporated under various forms of legislation-Commonwealth, State or Northern Territory-a mechanism whereby a national Aboriginal land rights network would be established.

In response to Senator Coulter, who argued that there could well be a need for this in many cases, I want to make the very important point that ATSIC is dealing with funds derived from the Australian taxpayer. This is very different from many other measures and needs. We constantly have to bear in mind that the budgetary and financial provisions that are going to flow to ATSIC, and will subsequently lead to what could be the development of quite extensive land acquisition programs, will be provided by the Australian taxpayer. It could well be that those funds, under the priorities determined by a commission, will not be used for the pressing social, economic development and education needs of Aboriginal people in Australia. By applying funds to a land bank that would be built up, advantages may well be gained for many Aboriginal people. But I would argue very seriously that that would not be the priority that the Australian people, through the taxpaying system of this country, would want to see in place.

TALK.START.PARA: -I think both Senator Coulter and Senator Tate missed the point of Senator Peter Baume's arguments. Senator Coulter took exception to the objective that Aboriginals should not be able to own land unless they occupied it. He told the Committee that land has different significance to Aboriginal people than it has to white people. We can accept that. Senator Baume pointed out-and I think this is the crux of the matter-that under the legislation as it stands at the moment, ATSIC could buy, purchase, control or put all its funds into land acquisition. They would be decisions that the commissioners could make and that land--
—But the Estimates procedure would eventually control it.

—It may control it but the budget, I believe, is around $800m. Under the legislation as it is proposed, a significant amount of money could go into land acquisition. As I understand him, Senator Baume is saying that there are priorities other than acquiring land. There is education, developing Aboriginal businesses, sewerage, roads-all the things that the ATSIC legislation has to provide for.
—Do you not think the ATSIC commissioners will get the balance right?
—I am sure they will get it right but I also think that this legislation cannot be open-ended. There may be people whose priorities will be to acquire land.
