TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I rose in the adjournment debate to talk about a particularly vexing problem for the Northern Territory in respect of stock routes and excisions. Tonight I rise to talk about a problem which the Territory has at the moment, which is of far greater proportions, and that is the airline pilots dispute. As a number of honourable senators have already said in this Parliament-my colleague in the House of Representatives, Warren Snowdon, and Senator Tambling on the other side of this chamber-this strike is having catastrophic effects on the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the airline pilots, who are a very privileged group of workers in this country, are paying some heed to the enormous damage that they are doing to this country while this dispute continues. I assume that they still want to call themselves Australians. I might add that one of the unwritten conditions of the very privileged awards that they have-with all this talk of going overseas and selling themselves at a moment's notice for twice the money-as well as the very good working conditions, is the great privilege of being Australians and living and working in this country.

One of the interesting things about the current state of the pilots dispute is that charter companies are making a great deal of money out of it. Indeed, they are taxing their aircraft and pilots to the limit. They have taxed their pilots to the point where they cannot continue to run all the very profitable charters. The charters are having a very small but definite impact on ameliorating the strike to some extent. I noted, not just in the Northern Territory but around Australia, that a significant number of these charter companies are operating what could be called strike-breaking flights with pilots from Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines at the controls.

It is interesting to note the actions that are being taken by these pilots. In the memo sent out by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) to its members two months before this strike started, advising them how to prepare for it financially, although lawn mowing business, painting the house and other things were mentioned, flying strike-breaking flights for charter companies was not. Nevertheless, a significant number of Ansett and Australian pilots are currently doing that. Perhaps I could suggest to them that, rather than flying with rubberband airlines, they would be far better off going the whole hog-getting back into big planes and flying for Ansett and Australian again.

The difficulty is that in terms of the current state of the dispute we have been hearing a great deal from the Opposition about what it would not do about it. The total state of disarray of the Opposition on this question is illustrated only too dramatically by the performance of its current leader, Andrew Peacock. If anyone doubts that, I commend to him the reading of the full transcript of the press conference on this dispute that the Leader of the Opposition gave the other day. A greater collection of nonsense one is never likely to see in one's life. He dug himself deeper and deeper into a hole.

I am reminded by the current performance of this Leader of the Opposition-in terms of his indecision and his complete lack of ability to get the two conflicting forces in his coalition on side-of a former conservative leader, Bonar Law, who, when he was having similar problems with his colleagues in 1912, uttered the immortal words, `I am their leader, I must follow them.' I think Andrew Peacock is following in that mode.

Many people have spoken on the radio about how to solve this dispute and a number of suggestions have been made, including the use of the Crimes Act against the pilots. I canvassed in some detail some of the sanctions that are already available through the Industrial Relations Commission or the courts in a speech last week and so I will not go over that list again. Suffice to say there are a number of problems in attempting to employ any one or a combination of those sanctions against the pilots. These difficulties arise largely from the fact that the pilots are no longer employees. Further action against the pilots union-for example, deregistration-may be feasible but would be likely to have little effect.

It must be noted, as I noted previously, that legislation introduced on a number of occasions by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) would be completely ineffective for similar reasons. Action could still conceivably be taken against the pilots under the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Crimes Act 1914. The basis of such action would not be any employer-employee relationship, but the continuing interference with interstate trade. It is probable that a dispute involving direct and/or secondary sympathy actions would be dealt with under the provision of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

In the case of action taken by pilots, section 45D (1A) provides the basis for bringing the dispute before the Federal Court. That section specifically makes it unlawful for two or more persons to combine to prevent or hinder interstate and/or overseas trade. Actions by other workers in sympathy with any action taken by the pilots would, in all probability, be caught by section 45D (1). Sections 45D (5) and (6) deem the relevant unions to be a party to any such action carried on by their members, unless the union can establish that it took all reasonable steps to prevent that action.

Under section 80 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 the court has the power to issue injunctions restraining persons from engaging in conduct constituting a boycott. Section 82 allows for actions for damages. Finally, section 76 allows for the imposition of pecuniary penalties. Maximum fines for each offence under this section are $50,000 for individuals and $250,000 for organisations. Actions under sections 45d and 45e are, however, subject to certain limitations. First, subsection 76 (2) provides that actions for pecuniary penalties under sections 45D and 45E cannot be brought directly against individuals. This gives some protection to individual unionists but not to their unions, nor does it protect the individuals from actions for damages or from contempt proceedings involving the breach of an injunction or other order of the court.

General statutory defences are available to actions brought under sections 45d and 45e, and there are specific defences to any action taken under section 45d (1a). Court decisions, including the Mudginberri case with which I am familiar, have severely limited the scope of the general defences to the point where the defences under section 45 (3) have generally been regarded as having no effect. Thus, the specific defences to actions under section 45d (1a) are unlikely to come into play in most disputes. It is not entirely clear that this is the case in the present dispute. Some attention has been given to the use of the Crimes Act in the current dispute as recently suggested by spokesmen for the tourist industry. As I pointed out in this House last week, using the Crimes Act was seriously considered by Bill McMahon, in the 1966 28-day Qantas strike. The problem here, however, is not necessarily one of jurisdiction but of the procedures required to invoke section 30j and the criminal penalties-maximum imprisonment of one year-that apply under that Act. The issuing by the Governor-General of a proclamation under section 30j would have much in common with the declaration of a state of emergency. Such an action, together with the possible gaoling of pilots, might be seen as excessive and would be seen as excessive by me. Amendments to the Crimes Act 1987 allow for fines as an alternative remedy to gaol.

The pilots have gone a long way towards convincing me that they are a special case. I have studied the history of the industrial record of that union, both here and in the United States of America. Some very interesting parallels are drawn between the operations of pilots' unions in Australia and in the United States. Indeed, as many senators would know, the working conditions under which Australian pilots fly are based on the working conditions of their North American counterparts, in particular, the incentive bidding system which is still used in this country. As I said last week, to quote the then President of the Pilots Federation, Captain R. Holt, when he introduced Reg Swartz to the annual conference of the Federation following the major dispute of 1966, `This Federation is unique in this country. We can do anything we like.' That has been the attitude consistently expressed by the Pilots Federation ever since then-that it is a unique body requiring special treatment. I agree with it. I think that it does need special treatment!

I am about to suggest a potential course of action that a future government could reasonably consider-not to resolve this current dispute, which I think will be resolved but not in the pilots' favour, but to prevent this kind of catastrophe from recurring. Indeed, governments must give consideration to this kind of action because of the role that aviation now plays in the Australian economy. The big difference between the disputes of 1966 and the industrial action taken from 1959 through to the 1960s, the early 1970s and now is that the airline industry in Australia plays a crucial role in our economy such as it has never played before. That handful of workers-1,600 of them-who are capable, at the snap of their fingers, of bringing the Australian airline industry to a complete halt and who are capable of inflicting such catastrophic damage to this country's economy and international reputation, have never been in this sort of position before. Times having changed as they have, a new look needs to be given to the way in which we deal with the aviation industry in Australia.

Tourism, for example, in terms of what has changed, has now become this country's greatest export earner. It earned $6.5 billion last year. The damage that has been done to long term tourism by this dispute is almost beyond calculation. In the Northern Territory where I come from thousands of forward bookings have been cancelled. A Japanese or American tourist with a couple of weeks recreation leave a year will not run the risk of running into this sort of problem again by booking next year's holiday to Australia in advance. It will be years before the ill-effects of the greedy actions of this small group on their fellow Australians are rectified.

The American experience has many parallels with the Australian experience. The most serious industrial action taken in this country in the airline industry to date was the strike in 1966. Interestingly enough, the most catastrophic strike in America's airline industry history was also in 1966. Perhaps the two strikes were not entirely unrelated. The other parallels that exist between the United States and here are of course the procedures used by the unions of playing one carrier off against another and then using the previous settlement as a starting point for the next. The other parallel between the two countries is that American pilots are very highly paid-as are their Australian counterparts-compared with other skilled people in the work force.

Therefore, government needs to have a complete and fresh look at the relevance of the airline industry to Australia and at the lessons that have been learnt from this dispute. The dispute is having a terrible effect on this country's economy and on the jobs of thousands of workers. To start with, 21,000 of the fellow workers of these pilots in the aviation industry will be thrown on the scrap heap if the strike continues for much longer. From the public statements that I have seen none of this seems to concern anyone in the Pilots Federation.

A new look needs to be taken at the relevance of this industry. We need a determination by future governments that this situation will never happen again. It may be necessary for future governments to enact special legislation, which can be done under the trade and commerce or corporations powers, to deal with this kind of dispute. I suggest that such legislation could be modelled on the United States Railway Labor Act of 1926 which specifically limits the right of parties to engage in collective bargaining in the interstate rail and air industries in the United States. Resorting to statutory cooling off periods of the type provided for in that Act may be of some assistance not only in resolving the current dispute, if such legislation had been in existence-I am not suggesting that it is practicable to introduce it at this point in the dispute-but also in dealing with similar claims by pilots if and when they arise in the future.

Two further advantages of such legislation are that it could be quarantined to the airline industry, as it is quarantined to very specific industries in the United States, and any sanctions contained in it need not involve imprisonment. Such legislation could be introduced without establishing a new range of sanctions and penalties which could be used against the trade union movement generally. The Railway Labor Act 1926 regulates labour management relations in the railroad and airline industries only in the United States of America. The legislation was extended to cover interstate airline operations in 1936. Recognising the peculiarities of the two industries, bargaining units operating under the Act are organised on a craft basis, not on an enterprise basis as is a common feature of industrial relations practice in the United States.

I will refer briefly to some of the detail of this legislation and explain why it operates in such a special way in respect of United States airlines. My source is the International Encyclopaedia for Labour Law and Industrial Relations, volume 10. It is a complex law but, in essence, it provides for a period of private settlement between the parties. If that fails the involvement of a national mediation board (NMB) is brought into play. During all the processes involved under this Act, long cooling off periods of between 30 days and 90 days are provided for. The matter then proceeds to arbitration, which, in the history of this procedure in the United States, is usually rejected by one or other of the parties to the dispute. I will quote directly from paragraphs 793 to 797 of the encyclopaedia as to what then happens:

If, as usually happens, one or both sides refuse to arbitrate, the NMB has two choices. One possibility is for it to withdraw from the conflict. If it does that, then no change in the status quo may be made for another 30 days. After that 30 days, the parties are free to resort to unilateral action and economic sanctions.
In other words, strikes. It continues:

The other option for the NMB is to notify the President of the United States that in its opinion the conflict threatens to deprive a section of the nation of an essential transportation service or that it threatens to `interrupt substantially' interstate commerce.
I think that both those conditions could be applied to the current dispute. It continues:

If the NMB chooses the latter course, the President, in his discretion, may create an emergency board and no change in the status quo is permitted until the ensuing special emergency dispute procedure has been exhausted.
I will briefly advise what the history of using this law is in the United States. The encyclopaedia continues:

Each year at least 500 contracts regulated by the RLA are amended or revised without resort to any of the formal steps involving NMB participation. In those cases in which NMB mediators do participate, over the years about 97 per cent have been resolved without a work stoppage. In Fiscal Year 1981, the NMB resolved 164 mediation cases.
As of the end of Fiscal Year 1981, in the 47 years of the NMB's existence, 193 emergency boards had been created.
That is, by the President of the United States. It continues:

According to the agency's evaluation of that experience: `In most instances the recommendations of the boards have been accepted by the parties as a basis for resolving their disputes without resorting to a final test of economic strength'. In addition to providing the parties with an opportunity to weigh the emergency board's recommendations and to afford the nation's chief executive an opportunity to informally cajole the parties into reaching a settlement, the 30-day waiting period following the emergency board's report also provides Congress with an opportunity to adopt special legislation dealing with the issues underlying the dispute. On occasion Congress has intervened at this point and imposed a legislative solution to the conflict.

The main feature of the Act, for the purposes of the discussion tonight, is that it places a legislative limitation on the extent to which contracts of employment can be reached through a process of free collective bargaining. Whereas strikes and lockouts are not unlawful-in fact they are a legitimate and integral part of the collective bargaining in most industries in the US-in the case of interstate transport, Congress has formed the view that the public interest needs to be protected from the undoubted industrial muscle of both the employers and the unions in this industry. Congress's response to what it saw as a special problem was to enact special legislation obliging the industrial parties in these sensitive industries to settle their differences `peacefully'. In doing so, the Congress recognised that even with the United States system's wealth of experience with collective bargaining, there are certain cases where market forces cannot be allowed free rein. The Opposition parties and members of the H. R. Nicholls Society have frequently pointed to the United States model as providing a useful basis for deregulating the Australian labour market. However, in the case of the present pilots dispute, they have failed to apply the same approach to the special circumstances of the domestic airline industry as was thought necessary in the United States.

In the heart of the sanctions package contained in the Australian Government's 1987 Industrial Relations Bill was the proposition that those who remain within the official industrial relations system-that is, organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-should be bound by the rules of that system. Registered organisations of employers and employees would be subject to sanctions and compliance measures contained or connected with the official system. Organisations which chose to remain outside the system or which were expelled from it would be liable to the sanctions of the general law of the land but not to the sanctions which form part of the official system of conciliation and arbitration. The 1987 Bill which would have brought consistency to the application of statute and common law in the area of sanctions was withdrawn because employer organisations either did not understand the Bill, could not explain it to their members or wanted to maintain the current legal position that puts registered organisations in double jeopardy by the use of the same legal sanction under both statute and common law.

This failure to rationalise the industrial sanctions has significantly undermined what would have been a major weapon in the current dispute: the threat of deregistration of the union. When I was reading the material on the subject, it was with great interest that I noted that after years in the wilderness the Australian Federation of Air Pilots was re-registered in 1986 by Mr Justice Jim Staples. He must be having a big laugh about it now. Perhaps it could be called Staples revenge. By remaining within the official system a union is effectively leaving itself open to two sets of sanctions: common law and statutory law. Unless there is a serious possibility that a union will fall apart in the wake of deregistration-that is, by having its membership taken up by other unions as was the case with the Builders Labourers Federation-the threat of deregistration is virtually no threat at all.

Much the same position applies where the union can organise mass resignations of its members. As we have seen in the present dispute where the employees bring the employment relationship to an end, the official sanctions are of limited value. I might add that the number of unions in this country whose members are well paid enough to play such a trump card is very few indeed. Even ignoring the Chaney Bill's many defects, that Bill does nothing to resolve the current dispute and it provides no long term remedy against future industrial action that may be perpetrated by the pilots.

Returning to the American model, it may be possible, and it certainly should be investigated in my view, to enact an Australian version of the Railway Labor Act 1926 and to quarantine that Act to the airline industry. I do not think a case could be made in Australia to apply it to the railway industry because that legislation does not have the same operative effect here as it does in the United States. This could be done by using the trade and commerce and/or corporations powers contained in the Australian Constitution. Under these powers a continuing employer-employee relationship is not required and the limited reach of the existing Act to non-employees could be extended without prejudicing the right of other registered organisations by further complicating the sanctions provision.

At the same time by confining the operation of a special Act to a particular organisation which has been removed from the system by deregistration or which has tried to avoid its responsibilities under the system, the Government would put new teeth into the deregistration sanctions. Given the alacrity with which the Commission cancelled the relevant pilots awards, there is little doubt in my mind that in this case had deregistration been a real threat the Commission or the court would readily have acted on any request to deregister the pilots union. Once deregistered the union would be liable to the unique set of sanctions contained in a railway labour-type Act. Fines and not draconian penal sanctions could be applied against the union and its members if they refused to observe the statutory cooling-off periods. The aircraft would consequently remain in the air while the dispute was arbitrated by a special panel similar to that employed under the United States legislation.

The pilots have stated again and again and, indeed, have indicated in every industrial dispute that they have pulled since 1959 that they want to be treated as a special case. I think there is a case for treating them as such and for agreeing to their request by the enactment of special legislation which would allow their wish to be granted whilst at the same time protecting the public interest without further adding to the morass of overlapping industrial sanctions. The one thing that has changed in the industrial disputation in this industry since the early 1950s is the absolutely crucial role that aviation now plays in Australia. The pilots are in a unique position. They run a closed shop union. It is a very tight shop indeed. The pilots are virtually irreplaceable which is their main bargaining strength and they have never hesitated to use it by playing one airline off against the other. In the past, as has been the case in the United States, one airline always crumbles. As soon as it does the new award that is negotiated under that agreement is then used as the basis for the next claim against another airline immediately, which is usually not very far down the track. That has been the history of this union in Australia for years.

The performance of the Opposition on this subject has been abysmal. I commend to all Opposition members, because some of them have perhaps not done so, a reading of the full transcript of their Leader's major press conference just the other day when he provided the Opposition's position on this particular dispute. I could not believe that someone could be in parliament for as long as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has been and make such a fundamental mess of what is without doubt the most pressing and crucial issue that is facing Australia today. It was with a sense of disbelief that I read Andrew Peacock's comments about this dispute. He wandered into the press conference, draped himself with all of his elegance and flair across the rostrum, and said to the assembled troops, `Well, boys, I told you I would have regular press conferences when I became Leader of the Opposition and here I am'. He was then completely thrown by the very first question he was asked which, funnily enough, was about the airline pilots dispute. He just dug himself deeper and deeper into a hole.

This episode reminded me of a conversation I had some years ago now with the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), on the steps of the old Parliament House. I was Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory at the time. I was doing an interview with a number of television channels on the Chamberlain case. John Howard, who I had never met and who was then shadow Treasurer, walked out of the front door of Parliament House and stood on the steps while I completed the interview. I have no doubt in my mind that there is no reason why John Howard would remember this conversation. Why would he? But I do. After the interview finished I walked over, shook hands with him, introduced myself and we had a chat on the steps. I remember saying to John Howard then, `You know, as someone who has been in Opposition for many years myself, I can tell you that you blokes will be in Opposition for a very long time if your party doesn't wake up to itself, get rid of that goose you have running your party at the moment and put you in'. Perhaps John Howard does remember that conversation. All I can say is that I believe that my political judgment at that time was absolutely correct. It is as correct now as it was then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks this evening are about India and Australia-India relations. The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is currently conducting a timely inquiry into Australia's relations with India. The Committee should finish its report before December this year. The Committee's three major terms of reference are Australia-India trade, India's defence capabilities and foreign relations in South Asia generally.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator actively engaged in this inquiry, I made my own arrangements to travel to India for three weeks last June and July. This visit to India was equally divided between Delhi, the capital, and the States of Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan. In Delhi I met government and military officers in the Departments of Defence, External Affairs, Commerce and the Planning Commission and some members of Parliament. I also met with some institute representatives and journalists concerned with trade or with defence and strategic assessments. I am particularly grateful to the Australian High Commissioner to India, His Excellency Graham Feakes, who with the assistance of his staff accompanied me and facilitated my arrangements in Delhi.

In Uttar Pradesh my wife and I were guests of the State Government and in particular our host was Dr Ammar Rizvi, Minister for Public Works, Chief Whip of the Congress Party and formerly a long time Uttar Pradesh Minister for Education. I visited universities and colleges in Lucknow, Pantnagar and Agra. In many meetings and conversations I extended my questions from the Delhi agenda to the context and to the insights and sense of priorities of this important province. Uttar Pradesh is a large Indian State, of course, with a population of 100 million people. In Rajasthan, our host was the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, the Hon. Giriraj Prasad Tiwari. This Parliament in Jaipur is located in the former city palace of the `pink city'. I met parliamentarians of all parties and other influential residents of the city. Besides Jaipur, I visited by car Bharatpur in the east of Rajasthan and Ajmer in the centre and met with a wide range of civic and educational leaders. Again I reflected on the defence, trade and foreign relations questions of the Delhi agenda, but this time in the provincial context of these three areas of Rajasthan.

My visit to India this year, apart from a brief reconnaissance in Delhi in 1987, was my first substantial return to the subcontinent in more than 20 years. In 1966-67, I was the leader of an Australian universities student delegation to India, Sri Lanka and Nepal, and I spent two months in India during that Australian summer. My travels then included the southern States, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Delhi, the States of the Indo-Gangetic plain from Punjab to Bengal, and the northern State of Kashmir. Perhaps I saw much more then as I travelled as a student, third-class on the trains, immersed among the people. Moreover, this original visit followed a year of university studies on the history and politics of India and Pakistan. Before returning this year I revised those studies and my foundation experiences in travelling in this important part of the world.

Let me draw to the attention of honourable senators some of my observations about India this year. At the outset, I wish to draw to the Senate's attention three notable speeches, three key speeches, all of which I would propose as essential reading for Australians wanting to come to grips with what is happening in India and with Australia-India relations. The first speech is by Rajiv Gandhi, the Indian Prime Minister. For five years he has led the Government of India since the assassination of his mother, Indira Gandhi, in 1984. At the end of his most fruitful and most authoritative year as Prime Minister-that is 1985, his first year in office-he was called on to give the inaugural address to the Centenary Session of the Congress Party in Bombay. It was 28 December 1985. It is a gutsy speech. It is a refreshing inspiration to truth and justice for India. After 100 years of Congress policies, Rajiv as Prime Minister is declaring that the Party and Government is failing the people of India, and he is calling for a revolutionary effort by his colleagues to overcome vested interests. His call is to serve the people. I seek leave to incorporate a summary of the speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

In his inaugural address to the Congress Centenary Session in Bombay on December 28, 1985, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi surveyed the history of the party and recalled its struggle for independence and for making India a modern self-reliant nation.

However, towards the end of the address he frankly criticised the administration, industry, trade unions, the education system, justice, the Congress Party and the Opposition. The following are his observations:
Institutions: Too often, behind their imposing facades, the spirit and substance lack vitality.
Justice: The poor have little hope of timely redress.
Industry: We have industrialists untouched by the thrusting spirit of great risk-takers and innovators.
Trade Unions: They now protect the few who have, oblivious of millions who have not. They feel little concern for the creation of national wealth, only for a larger and larger share.
Universities: Teachers seldom teach and students seldom learn. Strike, mass copying, agitations are more attractive alternatives.

Government Servants: We have government servants who do not serve but oppress the poor and the helpless, police who do not uphold the law but shield the guilty, tax collectors who do not collect taxes but conive with those who cheat the State.
Congress Party: Good Congress workers are handicapped for on their backs ride the brokers of power and influence, who dispense patronage to convert a mass movement into a feudal oligarchy.
Corruption is not only tolerated but even regarded as the hallmark of leaderships.
Opposition: Non-congress parties have shown a cynical disregard for sensitive issues of national security.
Mr Gandhi called for less consumption and more production and told the partymen to re-establish contacts with the masses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The single most distressing observation to make about India today is that Rajiv Gandhi's most important speech has fallen on deaf ears. Little progress towards the Rajiv reforms has been made in the past three years. Vested interests are even more entrenched. The Prime Minister seems to have given up on his proposed reform of the Congress Party. The Opposition is no better. Whilst the Opposition leader, Mr V. P. Singh, Rajiv's former Defence Minister, has put up some sharp and credible criticisms of the current Government, nevertheless the Janata Dal coalition offers no significant positive alternatives. In the States, the Opposition has made many gains, but for the coming national election, which is expected in October or December, Rajiv Gandhi is likely to be re-elected, but with a reduced majority. The overwhelming body of opinion in India is that the Prime Minister will continue with popular endorsement for another five-year term. Of course, his biggest asset is that his grandfather was Jawaharlal Nehru and his mother Indira Gandhi.

SPEECH.PARA: Rajiv's win will, in large part, rest on his strikingly new and positive policies towards the village councils all over India, the panchayat councils. He promises direct rather than indirect grants to the panchayat. Secondly, he promises open village council elections, the introduction of genuine democracy for the first time to the panchayat councils. These twin promises are keynotes to Rajiv's coming election victory. Rajiv's strategy is to restructure Indian politics by going around the vested interests even in his own Party, by denying power to the vested interests that have frustrated his December 1985 vision, and by giving power directly to the grassroots, to the ordinary people of India. This panchayat strategy has replaced his hope to reform the Congress Party.

However, there is one important power over Congress that the Prime Minister still holds, and in the next month he is likely to exercise this power because it can work alongside the panchayat reform. I refer to the Prime Minister's power of preselecting candidates for the coming election. I think that he will take many by surprise by putting up his own new alternatives to stand for the Congress I ticket, with the calculation that only a minority of those rejected will stand for the election independently with any prospect of success. I believe that the Prime Minister's power of preselection will cause a lot of excitement in the next few weeks.

The second speech to which I draw attention is the Tata Memorial Lecture of 12 April this year delivered in Bangalore by Dr Abid Hussain. Dr Hussain is a member of the Planning Commission of India and I have very much valued my discussions with him in Canberra in May and again in Delhi during my visit. Dr Abid Hussain is the most authoritative and perceptive Indian decision maker I have met. He has a most informed knowledge of his own country's political and economic development and his nature is generous and not arrogant towards others. In his Tata speech he elaborated on the foundations and objectives of India's upcoming five-year plan. The title is Eighth Plan: Some Strategic Perspectives. I seek leave to incorporate a few paragraphs of this speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-

The Eighth Plan is the eighth opportunity for us to restructure our society and influence our polity. It provides yet another occasion for articulating our loftiest hopes and noblest aspirations. It offers yet another chance to tackle our age-old problems with a renewed sense of commitment and vigour. It is yet another time for us to reflect on where we are going wrong and on what we should be doing different to promote growth and enhance equity. It is yet another moment to offer to our people a freshness of vision, a boldness of intent and a clarity of purpose to get the nation moving unitedly.

Seven Plans have come and gone by. Much has been achieved. The successes have been striking and cannot be wished away even by the prophets of statistical doom, of whom there is a surfeit in India. But the failures have been glaring. Our age-old problems of poverty and destitution, of hunger and malnutrition, of disease and squalor, of illiteracy and ignorance, of feudalism and inequality, of oppression and brutality persist. Economic progress is indeed taking place. The Indian economy is on a 5% growth trajectory. Industry and agriculture have taken impressive strides. A burgeoning middle class and a vibrant entrepreneurial class has come into being. But the pace of advance is still lethargic and more importantly, does not appear to be resulting in social well-being of society at large. The ghettoes of caste and tradition are getting fortified, just as prosperity is spreading.

While the signals for economic take-off have never been as promising as they are now, there seems to be a retrogression in social values and mores. Economic prosperity is breeding a dangerous kind of insularity, a pernicious kind of social Darwinism and a destructive kind of religious, linguistic and ethnic fundamentalism. The state, impressive as it appears with its bulging industrial muscle and growing agricultural prosperity, has been infiltrated by forces insensitive to the well-being and interests of the impoverished majority and is increasingly being alienated from its own people. The featherbedding combination of the bureaucrat and the politician is proving deadly and has succeeded in putting brakes on the forces of reform and change that found full expression in the Prime Minister's Congress Centenary Speech of 1985.

Quite simply, the design and working of the state apparatus and of its apparatchiks at all levels permits neither sustained rapid growth nor redistributive social justice in tangible measure. It is on this one single issue-of alternative and responsive state structures-that we need to focus our intellectual energies if planning is to be at all meaningful and if it is to make a real difference to peoples' lives. Just as Mr Gorbachov has realised that perestroika without glasnost is not possible, we too must appreciate that economic growth and social justice in India just cannot be sustained without root and branch reform and cleansing of our moribund administrative and political systems.

. . . The Eighth Plan strategy is designed to accelerate the growth rate of the economy from the 5% achieved in the 1980s to at least 6% . . . A 6% growth rate has certain macroeconomic implications that we need to understand and build a consensus on. First, it means a whole new approach to subsidies, which have been garnered by sections of society that can without it, whether it relates to fertiliser, food, export and credit subsidies. Targetting of subsidies is essential. Second, it means a containment in government's own consumption expenditure. Third, it means a vastly different policy regime for public enterprises that will involve a mix of closure, privatisation and transparency of all non-commercial obligations. Fourth, it implies a stepped up savings performance which in turn will demand a fresh look at the capital market. Finally, it means a 10% volume growth in exports, which is roughly double the Seventh Plan performance. This is feasible given sector-specific and firm-specific incentives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Let me emphasise that in 1984 in India an economic policy revolution was begun based on a new entrepreneurial economic plan of which Dr Abid Hussain was one of the principal architects. The plan was embraced by Rajiv Gandhi immediately on his succeeding his mother in office, although the plan was in train before then. He has put his strength behind the plan's aim to lower tariffs, increase exports and bring the disciplines of international competition to challenge-indeed, goad-the Indian economy towards improved performance. The eighth plan takes up this economic blueprint for a second successive five-year period.

SPEECH.PARA: The third speech to which I draw attention is that of the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his successful visit to Delhi in February this year. I refer actually to both his general speech of 9 February and his speech on 10 February to the India-Australia Joint Business Council. Mr Hawke's description of Australia-India relations and of the positive prospects for increased trade between our nations is a bipartisan matter in this Parliament. Government and Opposition alike want to build strongly on the vastly improved relationship between India and Australia which has so constructively developed since Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's successful visit to Australia in 1986. All the promise that we expressed to him then from both sides of Parliament has been fulfilled, and to the genuine mutual benefit of both countries. Much more is in prospect. I will not foreshadow the analysis of these developments in Australia-India relations, which will be set out in the Senate Committee's report.

More briefly, I should refer to two recent books which ought to be widely read. One is by an Australian historian, Dr Robin Jeffery, titled What's Happening in India, published in 1986, which uses as its springboard the contemporary tensions, opportunities and wealth of the Punjab. The other is the book by Indian journalist, M. J. Akbar, titled India: the seige within. This is understandably popular in Indian Government circles as it is a bold self-justification of an aspiring, expansive `greater India'. It is a disturbing book for neighbouring Pakistanis because it represents all the more evidence for being anxious that increasing numbers of Indians are rejecting the 1947 partition of the subcontinent as a mistake which was against the pre-Mogul destiny which India, now that it is `free', should be able to again pursue. I am not a convert to Akbar's nationalism, but it must truly be understood.

I now turn briefly to some general conclusions about Australia-India trade. Currently, Australia exports half a billion dollars worth of goods to India. India exports a quarter of a billion dollars worth to Australia. The prospects for growth in this two-way trade are very positive indeed. We need to look far beyond simple commodity trade in wool, coal, iron ore and wheat to see the real growth prospects in Australia's high-tech products, telecommunications, education services, construction consultancies and financial services. On our part we need to go beyond traditional Indian goods such as textiles, clothing and footwear and tea and coffee, to chemicals, computer software and manufactured goods wherever India puts up products competitive both in quality and in price. As one senator who, over the last 10 years, has helped to build the enormously increased trade between China and Australia, I should add that our recent success in east Asia to develop improved markets should not blind us to the parallel opportunities in south Asia and in India in particular. Australian analysts and planners such as my friend Dr Ross Garnaut should ensure that we keep east Asia and south Asia in a proper perspective. Our vision for Australian trade must encompass both-indeed, all fruitful markets anywhere in the world.

I will refer briefly to India's enhanced defence capabilities, which will be carefully addressed in our Senate report. Over the past year increased attention has been given to India's increased naval expenditure; the two aircraft carriers and the plan to acquire three; the leasing of a nuclear powered submarine and the plan to acquire six; the test firing of the Agni intercontinental missile, which has a range of 2,500 kilometres; the decade and more that has elapsed since India first tested a nuclear explosive device; the constant speculation that India has become the sixth or seventh nuclear armed nation; and the continuing equipment and training of the third largest army in the world and one of the most lethal air forces. All these military acquisitions need to be taken into account when we come to assess the defence capabilities in the nations bordering on the Indian Ocean, a region in which Australia and our neighbours of the Association of South East Asian Nations are very much placed, let alone Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and the other countries of the south Asian region.

It is my observation that India justifies her strong military policy with reference to several very plausible arguments that we in Australia must realistically face. One is that, if nuclear capability is the currency of world power, India sees no reason why she should not acquire that nuclear capability. Another argument is that the nuclear non-proliferation treaty was designed by the nations of the world to stop horizontal proliferation and in particular to prevent India from acquiring nuclear weapons. India is, therefore, subjectively quite committed never to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

A third common argument in India looks to the track record in defence needs since India's independence in 1947. There was the major war with China in 1962 and three wars with Pakistan. It is India's view that there is a need for that country to be prepared against the worst case of a combined or allied attack by both China and Pakistan together. A fourth argument that is much mentioned in India is that the military budget is a low percentage of gross national product and is comparable with the percentage in most countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Another argument that is much used in India is that India in its general values is still much guided by the principles of the first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, and the other guiding spirit, Mahatma Gandhi, who espoused so directly the principles of peace and international cooperation.

Each one of those five arguments commonly put in India can be questioned. I do not accept any one of the five arguments with any kind of complacency. Part of our need in Australia is to apply objective evidence to each of the five arguments or assertions that are commonly made in India. There are also a number of counter-arguments and other considerations that we in Australia would need to take into account. Firstly, there is no defence plan in India. There is no White Paper on defence. There is no explicit government policy as to what India's defence capability seeks to achieve. Secondly, we need to be concerned about continuing our strong commitment to support the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. It is a bipartisan matter in this Parliament not only for us to strengthen that treaty, as we did in its recent confirmation discussions, but also to follow up the comprehensive set of disarmament measures to which Australia is committed. Happily, India shares some of those disarmament objectives but not, I am afraid, all of them.

Another consideration is that Australia is deeply committed to doing all that we can do to reduce tensions in south Asia and to discourage any arms race in the region with either conventional or nuclear weapons. We should not lose sight of the fact that Australia is also concerned on account of India's interventions into the affairs of other countries in the region, that India is seen too much by its neighbouring countries as a regional bully that has over-exerted its own policies and backed up its foreign policies with military strength. Examples of this are the intervention with Pakistan in the formation of Bangladesh; the occupation at the moment of the northern part of Sri Lanka by the Indian Army, despite the President of Sri Lanka directly requesting the Indian Army to leave; the difficulties with Bangladesh; and the closing of the borders between India and Nepal-not to mention some differences of opinion between India and Bhutan or the paratroopers who were flown in to stop a coup in the Maldives.

These military activities and interventions by India all pale into insignificance given the enormous tension that still exists between India and Pakistan and the hot war that is currently under way on the glacier to the north of Kashmir. In regard to these interventions, Australia and all nations are rightly concerned that India's professions of justice and fairness with regard to the sovereignty and independent foreign policies of neighbouring countries are being followed up in practice by fair dealing.

Australians rightly should be concerned at India's ambitious, but often ambiguous, objective not only to become a regional power in south Asia but also to join the superpowers. Many people in India believe that their country should aspire to be in the top club of the most powerful nations in international affairs. Indians refer to the United States of America, the Soviet Union, China and themselves. It is still frequently lamented that, for example, India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council. India has often explicitly aspired to be the exclusive military power in the Indian Ocean. These considerations, along with our scepticism of the arguments that I first rehearsed, and that are frequently put in India, all need to be considered together in our assessment of the meaning and possible outcomes of India's enhanced defence capabilities.

In conclusion, I wish to express my thanks to those hosts who welcomed me and my wife during our visit to India. I also wish to thank the Australian High Commissioner and his staff in Delhi and the wider circle of the Australian Foreign Office who, in briefings and in other ways, made my visit more successful. I wish to thank a wide range of Australian academics and business leaders involved in Australia-India trade and members of the research staff of the Parliamentary Library who assisted me in preparing for this visit. I look forward to the presentation later this year of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia-India relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to analyse the decisions and the findings of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. Although I have previously spoken on this matter, I feel that it is necessary to reiterate and add to what I have said. I have already asked for the Tribunal to be recalled and for its devastating and disastrous decisions and effects on the pharmaceutical industry to be reconsidered. I again wish to state that I have a vested interest, through my wife who is a local part time pharmacist. A number of my constituents who are pharmacists have really got-to quote them-their `backs to the wall' as a result of these findings. They are really desperate people. Their livelihoods, their means of earning a living, are now at stake. These comments have been made not by one or two pharmacists but by a significant number of pharmacists in Tasmania, and their concerns are echoed right around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The findings on which the Tribunal has based its decisions are flawed. The Tribunal presented a database which included information from about 150 selected pharmacies throughout Australia. But many of the 150 selected pharmacies did not respond. The main reason for this lack of response was the lack of time involved and the amount of detail that was required to complete the surveys. Actually, there were two components to the survey: firstly, 120 pharmacies were asked to complete an individual work measurement recording exercise. One pharmacist who started to participate stated that he and three of his staff members each spent six hours attempting to complete this survey and it was still far from finished. After 24 hours of work by four people, the task was still far from finished. Secondly, the survey required the gathering of other information that involved the services of pharmacists' accountants. There was no question of the Tribunal covering the costs involved in accountants completing the survey. These costs involved many hours of work by a pharmacist, his staff and his accountant.

A large number of pharmacists found that it was quite uneconomic to complete this first part of the survey. The second aspect of the survey was a sub-sample of 30 pharmacies selected from the original 150. These 30 pharmacies were requested to complete a 1988 pharmacy costs of goods sold survey. They were asked to supply the following:
All supplier invoices and statements relating to goods and services purchased for the above pharmacy for the 12 months ended 30 June 1987.
All supplier invoices and statements relating to goods and services purchased for the month ended 29 February 1988.
Where the information is not already shown on the invoices or statements separate details of all-
remember the period that I mentioned-
special pack buys
discounts
rebates
surcharges
special promotions; and
any other payment or deduction which had an impact on your purchase price and cost of goods sold for the year ended 30 June, 1987 and the month ended 29 February 1988.

Just imagine going through all those invoices in a busy pharmacy. The time involved in gathering all this information was monumental and quite unreasonable, yet the time given to complete the survey forms was minimal. One pharmacist selected in my electorate was given 10 days to supply this sort of detail which covered an extended period. Naturally, many of the pharmacists did not have the time to respond. Granted, the Tribunal offered an extension, but no offer to compensate for the cost of the time involved was forthcoming. There was a token gesture-a reverse charge telephone call was offered by the consultants, Deloitte Consulting Group Pty Ltd. The cost of the freight of the invoices I have mentioned was also offered but no coverage of the cost of pharmacist hours lost, accountants' costs and staff costs was forthcoming.

It is believed by many pharmacists that those who responded to the survey were either extraordinarily efficient or extraordinarily inefficient or they did not need to supply many scripts. Thus 0.3 per cent of the pharmacists in Australia responded to this survey. Is this a sufficient base on which to restructure the entire pharmaceutical industry? It is an unacceptable criterion for assessing pharmacists' income. The Government has supported the database findings because it thinks it will save money on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). However, it is cutting the gross remuneration to or gross income of the pharmacies.

A business cannot readily change its fixed costs but it can change its variable costs. Naturally, the first variable cost to be changed will be the labour component. I have already mentioned this in my previous address. But I think the Senate needs to know that, throughout Australia, there are 16,000 pharmacy assistants whose jobs are now threatened. If General Motors-Holden's Ltd, the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd, or even Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd were facing stand-downs of this magnitude, the headlines of the newspapers would be screaming.

The effect of the Tribunal's decision is that an average pharmacy will lose $26,000 to $30,000 in a year. These are the wages for two or maybe even three assistants, depending on their ages. We have not even begun to discuss the pharmacists who will close their shops. A figure of over 100,000 has previously been stated. Many country and smaller pharmacies that employ one, two or three staff members will become family businesses. The staff will be retrenched and the wife withdrawn from home duties to work in the pharmacy. The pharmacist himself could possibly not draw a salary and the business may make only a small profit or loss, or he might eventually decide to close. This is the possible scenario being painted for many pharmacists right across Australia.

Many pharmacists have invested up to $500,000 in buildings, stock and fixtures and fittings to set up as a business. This $500,000 does not include goodwill. The Government argues that goodwill should not be included as an asset in the funds-employed component of the formula used to determine the remuneration. After what the pharmacies are going to go through, it is probably true that the goodwill of pharmacies will not be worth anything as a result of this Tribunal hearing. The Government falsely argues that goodwill is an intangible asset-we all know that-with varying definitions and methods of treatment, that its value is generally subjective, and that inclusion of goodwill in the funds-employed component would lead to excess payments to pharmacists. Goodwill should be taken into account when calculating a reasonable return on an investment. In moving into his practice, a pharmacist has to pay out. It is reasonable that it is taken into account. A country that does not allow a reasonable return on a business will find that that business is stifled over time. It will not enhance the overall economic state of the country. It is true that pharmacies are being offered $50,000 to amalgamate. So $50,000 for a $500,000 business does not really sound like a generous offer to me.

In many cases there are requests for amalgamation where there is enough business at the present time for two pharmacies or more. In Deloraine, which is a small country town in my own State of Tasmania, there are two pharmacies. Both earn modest incomes and the pharmacies provide jobs for five to six assistants plus the pharmacists. They are being asked to amalgamate; yet the three banks in the town are not being asked to join forces. The pharmacists are being singled out.

If the $20m saving forecast by the Tribunal is to be achieved, it will be at the expense of retrenchments of many thousands of pharmacy assistants, and these assistants are usually young and female. This is an age group that already has a very high and unacceptable unemployment rate. At the moment Tasmania has, I think, a 12.4 per cent unemployment rate compared with the national average of 7.5 per cent in the 15- to 19-year-old age bracket. In 1987, this rate was as high as 19.4 per cent in Tasmania. A return to these sorts of figures could easily eventuate if the Tribunal's findings are implemented.

The Tribunal has further ignored the increased cost of running this type of business. In the last five years, the cost of pharmacy goods has risen by 101.5 per cent and labour costs by 87 per cent. Yet the pharmacists' gross income has increased by a very much smaller margin. It appears that the pharmacists are being singled out for quite punitive treatment by this Government. Now, to add insult to injury, the Government is going to abide by the decisions of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal. The database finding is compounding the damage to pharmacists. The Government has already cut the real income of pharmacists by some 12 per cent last year and is planning to cut it by a further 8 per cent or even more this year. This has already caused the closure of many pharmacies. The Government is preventing pharmacists from sharing the gains they have achieved for the community in developing more efficient pharmaceutical services-for example, through computerised information on therapeutic drugs.

A further bone of contention is the value that the Government places on the pharmacist-proprietor. The Federal Government has submitted that the proprietor's notional salary should be $15 per hour. This is less than half of the equivalent hourly rate for middle range government salaried pharmacists. Is it reasonable that pharmacists should be discriminated against in this way compared with other professions? I believe that discrimination, even within a profession-the private sector versus the public sector-is quite unreasonable. The $15 an hour rate is considerably less than even tradespersons charge nowadays. Is this fair recompense? Certainly not, particularly considering that they provide a community service which is important to the health of our nation.

Another one of my constituents-and I believe that taking examples is important because only in this way can we sheet home the gravity of what has been perpetrated on these people-is a small country pharmacist who has given me the following facts: He works 51 hours per week over seven days. He provides home delivery services after hours, sometimes travelling 52 kilometres to make a delivery. Most of his clients are age pensioners and many have limited access to transport. He dispenses between 11,000 and 12,000 prescriptions per year and has recently installed a computer at a cost of $6,250 to provide an even better service to the community, for no extra remuneration. Dispensing prescriptions provides around 55 per cent of his sales, the majority of his other sales also being in health related areas. So nearly all of his dispensing involves PBS items. Award wages for the hours worked, including penalty rates, are approximately $43,000. This includes holidays and sick pay. But this particular pharmacist does not get the $43,000. His trading profit for 1988-89 will be $28,000, without deducting the proprietor's salary. The latest Tribunal findings will cost him between $5,000 and $6,000 a year, because he is a small pharmacist, which will leave him around $22,000 a year as a professional with life or death responsibilities being faced every day in the execution of his duty.

The restructuring of the dispensing fee and the abolition of the present 25 per cent mark-up on the wholesale price of drugs will mean that many pharmacists will actually be losing money on the dispensing of many expensive items. For example, the Government works on a price list for wholesale drugs. The wholesalers charge a 6.2 per cent surcharge in order to encourage the purchase of bulk quantities and the surcharge is rebated if the quantities are high enough. But not every pharmacy can afford to buy in bulk. Thus, if a drug which costs $100 is ordered, the surcharge being $6.20 and the dispensing fee from the Government being $4.20, a loss of $2 occurs. This could be handed on to the consumer, but he certainly will not appreciate it.

A consequence of this situation will be that many pharmacists will not stock the expensive sorts of drugs. The consumer will be encouraged to go to the public hospital to obtain a drug, at great inconvenience to many of these old people. A drug that could be affected in this way is Renitec. As I have mentioned previously, this is what is known as an ACE inhibitor. It is a new, expensive drug which is commonly requested for hypertension. The drug which is replacing four or five other drugs which have been previously prescribed. It is expensive cost-wise, but it does not have the same side effects of the previously prescribed drugs, and it helps in preventing the hospitalisation of patients. The cost to the public health system will far outweigh the savings that the Government feels it is going to obtain by implementing the Tribunal's findings, especially if these expensive drugs are available only from the public hospitals.

The Government says that it cannot circumvent the Tribunal's decisions. In the past, when it has suited the Government, tribunals' decisions have been ignored. Two years ago, the Government circumvented the then tribunal and reduced the wholesale price of drugs. This was outside the bounds of the tribunal. The Government also stepped in to stop the massive increases that judges were granted by a tribunal set up to investigate the salaries of this august body.

At the moment, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, Hon. Peter Staples, is considering asking pensioners to pay $2 or $3 for each of their scripts. There are 150 million pensioners' scripts dispensed each year. The Government will earn $300m from this. Is Mr Staples considering using this to give the pensioners a pay increase? Is this the intended plan of the Government in enforcing the Tribunal's decision? What sort of pension increase will there be?

The Pharmaceutical Remuneration Benefits Tribunal has caused and is going to cause untold financial damage to pharmacists, their businesses and employees, and to the economy if these findings are allowed to stand. I hope that the Government will intervene, overturn these decisions and implement something that is more reasonable to the pharmacists, to the community and to the health care of ordinary Australians throughout this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a major meatworks in Portland for many years. It is known as Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd. It has been a profitable enterprise. When it is operating, hundreds of people work there. Their pay has provided good times for Portland. On 29 April 1988 Borthwicks dismissed its work force. It said that livestock was too expensive and in any event was in short supply. At the time of its shutdown in April 1988 Borthwicks had been operating for some years according to an agreement with the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. That agreement provided for wages and conditions very similar to all other export works in Victoria. In October 1988 Borthwicks spoke of reopening the meatworks. It said that those it employed would have to accept lower wages and conditions than those operating in April.

SPEECH.PARA: When this declaration was made in October 1988 Borthwicks was owned by Australian Meat Holdings. Australian Meat Holdings was once shared by Tancreds, Elders IXL Ltd, Smorgon Consolidated Industries and Metro Meats Ltd., but during most, if not all, of the events I am to relate it was solely in the hands of Elders IXL. People who traditionally worked at Borthwicks declined to accept the reduced conditions offered by Elders IXL. The matter was taken before Commissioner Caesar. During one hearing he made a statement which the employer and employees interpreted differently. Talking about the construction of an award, the statement was:
On that construction then the present application in the form set out in relation to Borthwicks amounts to a roping-in application.
In all the circumstances I will adopt the submissions of both Mr Burdis and Mr Rothman and adjourn the matter to a date to be fixed to allow the proper serving of the parties.

In the meantime I strongly recommend that the current practices carried out by the employers of meatworks labour in Victoria continue until any proceedings before the Commission require them to change. This recommendation applies to all employers of meatworks labour in Victoria including Borthwick Pacific.

The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, which represented the employees, took this to mean that conditions applicable to export meatworks throughout Victoria would apply to Borthwicks. The employer thought differently. The Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission took over the dispute. The union was anxious to have the matter disposed of. The Commission sat during January. It concluded taking evidence on the Australia Day holiday, 30 January 1989. The urgency in taking evidence did not produce an expeditious decision. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which took evidence in January, had become the Australian Industrial Relations Commission by the time it handed down a decision on 23 March 1989. It urged the parties to draw up a new award. The last paragraph of the decision reads:
In our view, conferences should now take place between the parties on the terms and conditions of employment which should apply under the new award to operate at Portland. Deputy President Riordan-
he was appointed pursuant to section 34 of the old Act-

will be available to assist the parties in these conferences. In the event that full agreement is not achieved on the terms and conditions of the proposed award, this Bench will reconvene to consider the procedure to be adopted in the resolution of the matter.

The parties were unable to come to terms. The Industrial Relations Commission brought down an award in June 1989. This was roughly six months after the dispute giving rise to it was notified. The rancour left by the dispute would be less had the award been delivered earlier. Time allows divisions to harden. The award contained disappointments for the union. However, in clause 35 it did provide for seniority. Elders IXL did not comply with that clause. The union complained to the Commission, which said it could do nothing.

Elders IXL advertised for employees under the new award. People applied. The company sent them to a particular doctor in Portland. He reported to Elders on their physical ability to carry out the work required. Elders did not pay for the certificates. The candidates were told to use their Medicare entitlements. This caused concern because the Medicare scheme is not intended for the purpose to which it was put. One applicant was diagnosed as having a murmur in the heart. This caused him and his family a great deal of worry. Investigations by other doctors showed the diagnosis to be wrong. The situation produced was most unhappy.

Much has been said about the need to free up the labour market. The call has been for workers and management to negotiate enterprise agreements. Unions have been allotted a minor role in the scheme of things. But for the unions conditions provided by Elders IXL at Portland would be the poorer. A situation has been created where people looking for work must use Medicare to pay for a report from the single doctor to whom the company sends them. This fits awkwardly with the concept of a caring employer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I apologise for taking up the time of the Senate at this hour of the night. I would not have done what I am going to do but for the comments made by Senator Collins which took 26 minutes of our time. It was simply an undisguised and unveiled attack on Mr Peacock, the Liberal Party leader. The honourable senator's speech was in the guise of making comment about the solution of the present strike which is crippling this country, but there was no constructive comment at all in the 26 minutes from the former not only failed State member of parliament but failed Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory. It was just a diatribe against Mr Peacock.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand why the Australian Labor Party is doing this. It is way behind in the polls and it is going to stay that way. We have been subjected to the most intense attack through the press and from the Labor Party of any leader of any party I have seen in my lifetime. But it does not matter. Mr Peacock has broad shoulders; we all have broad shoulders. It is not only Mr Peacock's qualities and the policies of the Liberal Party that are putting us ahead. It is also the high interest rate regime-under which people cannot buy houses-and the high taxes, that this Government has imposed on the community that have dug the grave for this tired Government. The reason why we have a strike at the moment is that we have failed policies, and the belief that in some way we can run a centralised wage policy and control every matter in a complex economic environment to run the whole nation's economy by some government official or through some bureaucracy. We simply cannot do it.

Interestingly enough, from my reading I find that it was only in 1944 that the doctrine was laid down in the British Parliament whereby it was possible for governments to control and manage an economy entirely. Of course, if we go back historically before that governments did not believe that they could control the economies. They did not have this universal belief. The tide has gone out. It has had more than a fair trial. We have seen 40 or 50 years of governments trying to control every cent that is spent and guide the economies. Even the Soviets, who are not terribly fast learners, have realised it has failed. The Labor Party has still not caught up with what the Soviets and the Chinese have learnt.

I do not want to debate the solution to the problem that the Liberal and National parties will impose. We are not in government. Furthermore, had we been in government the situation would never have arisen. We now have to resolve the situation. It is only going to be resolved through negotiation. I would like to spend one minute reflecting on what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is proposing. The Prime Minister has said-I have heard him say this repeatedly-that there is a 6 per cent maximum within the guidelines that the pilots could be awarded. He has forbidden the airlines to negotiate on terms other than that. What is the Prime Minister saying? Apart from all the abuse that is being heaped on a professional body with all its skills he is saying to them-I have heard him say this-that they can all leave Australia. What is going to happen if they all leave Australia?

Quite clearly the Prime Minister sees himself as a latter day President Reagan, in the way President Reagan dealt with the air traffic controllers. He wants to fire them all and recruit fresh ones. The only way he is going to get fresh pilots is to bring them in from overseas. Does the Prime Minister really want to drive more than 1,600 of our finest airmen in this country out of Australia? That is what he is talking about. We have 1,600 of the top professionals in their field who are as good as or better than any other pilot corp in the world. The Royal Australian Air Force has the best pilots. Between 450 and 600 of the most capable RAAF pilots have joined that pilot corps in the last three or four years.

Pilots are a national resource. One day I want to make a speech in this Senate about the importance of pilots to this country, because I believe that they are a national resource. The way they are trained, developed, brought on line and employed deserves a great deal more attention than any government gives to it. I come back to what Mr Hawke wants to do. If he wants to drive the 1,600 pilots out of Australia, he will eviscerate completely Australian aviation. We will have nothing at all left. Mr Hawke will be doing what the Pol Pot regime tried to do to the educated class in Cambodia, formerly called Kampuchea. It is precisely the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't the Government let the pilots and the airlines talk?

—I do not know that answer. It is the most obvious thing that should happen. If we drive these pilots out and recruit from overseas, there are certain practicalities we need to consider. The training requirements are enormous and we do not have any pilots who can act as training captains because they have all resigned. We have a recency requirement in this country that a pilot needs to have flown within 30 days to hold currency on his licence. That will expire very shortly for most pilots unless they are brought back quickly. How are we to train 1,600 pilots from all around the world? What is the cost? What is the time? It is not a matter of days, as the aNiMaLs-that is, the National Media Liaison Service-are telling the people of Australia through the press corps at the moment. It is a matter not of days or weeks, but of months-probably four to six months. It would be a huge cost. What would we have at the end of the day?
—It doesn't work like that.

—That is right. It does not work like that because Australian airlines work with a rostering pool. The degree of training is such that any captain in a company can be assigned to fly with any first officer and any flight engineer. The airlines can do that because those people are trained in the company system. They can mix anyone, the most junior pilot who has a licence with the most senior captain, and they will get a safe and effective crew. If we are to pick up pilots from all around the world and run them through a crash training program, we will lose all that flexibility in crew training and manning. Again, that will result in great operational limitations and huge costs, not only to the airlines, but also to fare paying passengers. To think that the solution is to bring in 1,600 pilots from overseas is just cloud-cuckoo-land. I come back to the point that there must be negotiations. We have said that time and time again.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now deal with the point of Senator Collins's speech in which he raised the red herring of the Railway Labor Act of 1926 in the United States of America. The first point I make about that is that there is simply no time now when we are in this situation to introduce legislation. If we want legislation, we should introduce it before there is a strike rather than when we are dealing with it. It is just not practical to introduce legislation now. The second point I would make about it is that I do not know the Act except from Senator Collins's explanation of it. Senator Collins said that the Railway Labor Act of the USA was an interstate Act relating to transport. The year 1926 occurred 63 years ago. My knowledge of the United States transport scene tells me that the legislation has not worked at any time in any way at all.

Senator Collins told us that there had been a huge strike in the United States in 1966, at the same time as we had a strike in Australia. I do not remember that but I do remember-you probably do also, Mr President-the huge strike of Northwest Orient Airlines within the last five or six years. Northwest Orient is one of the big operators in the United States, in both internal and overseas airlines systems. Those involved did not go on strike for two or three weeks or two or three months. They went on strike for something like 10 or 12 months; it might even have been 15 or 16 months. It was a huge strike. The Railway Labor Act of 1926 did nothing to mitigate the intensity of that strike.

At present, Eastern Air Lines is on strike-again, one of the very big airlines of the United States. The strike started somewhere around the middle of March this year. So far as I know, it is still running. I make the point that Senator Collins has probably just picked this thing up out of a book. What he is proposing clearly has never worked in the United States and I do not believe that it would work in Australia. We have to get a system that the Liberal and National parties propose of having voluntary agreements. Parties join such agreements of their own volition. If one party or the other breaches it, that party can be sued for breach of contract. We do not wish to coerce everyone into voluntary agreements. If people wish to stay in the present system, some penalties have to be introduced into the arbitration system. That is what I think poor Senator Collins, in his blind way, was groping towards. He was trying to say that we have to get some penalties into the system.
